detectors at the four node outputs plus two ancilla detectors.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of a wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router in an integrated photonic circuit. Instead of generating a fixed entangled state, the chip should perform one of two entanglement-swapping operations\u2014between remote nodes A&C or between B&D\u2014based solely on the polariton-wavelength of a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and if that photon is prepared in a superposition of the two wavelengths, the router will implement a coherent superposition of the two swap outcomes (a first step toward indefinite-order entanglement distribution). \n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]  (targets A & C)  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]  (targets B & D)  \n   \u2022 Single-photon control E \u2192 mode [4]  (prepared in |\u03bb\u2081\u27e9 or |\u03bb\u2082\u27e9 or their superposition)\n\n                   \u2193\n  integrated linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   D2 D3   D4 D5\n   (A  C)  (B  D)  (ctrl anc)\n\nOperation & targets:\n \u2022 If the control photon is in wavelength \u03bb\u2081, the linear network should route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the coherent sum of those two orderings, yielding a superposed entanglement link.  \n \u2022 The chip\u2019s success is heralded by distinct 3-click patterns: one signature for \u201cA\u2013C swapped,\u201d another for \u201cB\u2013D swapped,\u201d each correlated with which control-ancilla detector clicked.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled entanglement-swap router on chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (control emitter at mode 4)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4]  \n \u2022 pair sources: [[0,1], [2,3]]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two sets of detector-click signatures, one for each swap outcome, plus their coherent superposition.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this is powerful and extensible:\n 1) Introduces the first on-chip, passive quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength as a control qubit to choose and even superpose which remote link is entangled.  \n 2) Lays groundwork for indefinite-order entanglement distribution and multi-channel routing by simply adding more wavelengths and sources.  \n 3) Fully matches Pytheus\u2019s abstract model\u2014probabilistic pair sources, a single-photon emitter, a static interferometer, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014without requiring feedback or cavities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates The goal is not state generation but a single static linear\u2010optical network that, given three unknown qubits (photons each in \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) plus a small ancilla resource, unambiguously projects them onto one of the eight GHZ basis states:\n  |GHZ\u00b1\u2080\u27e9 = (|000\u27e9 \u00b1 |111\u27e9)/\u221a2  \n  |GHZ\u00b1\u2081\u27e9 = (|001\u27e9 \u00b1 |110\u27e9)/\u221a2  \n  |GHZ\u00b1\u2082\u27e9 = (|010\u27e9 \u00b1 |101\u27e9)/\u221a2  \n  |GHZ\u00b1\u2083\u27e9 = (|100\u27e9 \u00b1 |011\u27e9)/\u221a2  \n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit A \u2192 modes [0,1] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit B \u2192 modes [2,3] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit C \u2192 modes [4,5] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)\n   \u2022 Ancilla photons from one pair source \u2192 modes [6,7]\n   \u2022 Ancilla single emitters \u2192 modes [8],[9]\n\n                   \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5   D6  D7   D8  D9\n\nConfiguration hints for pytheus:\n \u2022 description: \u201cIntegrated GHZ\u2010basis analyzer for frequency\u2010bin qubits.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 3  (one pair source at [6,7], two single_emitters [8,9])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [8,9]  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[6,7]]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the eight GHZ basis strings (e.g. \u2018000111\u2019, \u2018111000\u2019, \u2018001110\u2019, \u2026) mapped onto eight distinct sets of 4\u20136 click signatures across D0\u2026D9.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this matters:\n 1) First on\u2010chip, wavelength\u2010encoded GHZ\u2010basis measurement, a foundational tri\u2010partite network primitive.  \n 2) Enables multi\u2010node entanglement\u2010swapping, teleportation, and nonlocality tests in the frequency domain.  \n 3) Directly generalizable to larger GHZ analyzers (d\u2010level, N\u2010party) by adding wavelengths and ancilla.  \n 4) Fully compatible with pytheus: abstract modes, probabilistic/single\u2010photon sources, static interferometer, number\u2010resolving detection\u2014no feedback or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The ensemble already contains multiple GHZ basis analyzers (both reconfigurable and on-chip versions). To be novel at the PRL level, you must introduce a fundamentally new feature\u2014such as nontrivial multi-frequency interference effects, topological protection of the GHZ projection, adaptive or indefinite-order measurement control, or a nonlinear/measurement-based extension beyond standard linear-optical ancilla-assisted GHZ analysis.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d and \u201cintegrated photonic circuit\u201d into a novel quantum\u2010network measurement (no state generation):\n 1) A 4-mode \u201cquantum switch\u201d that uses a control photon\u2019s polariton\u2010wavelength to passively route which of two Bell-measurements occurs first, creating a superposition of swapping orders (indefinite\u2010order entanglement swapping).  \n 2) A dual\u2010wavelength Hong-Ou-Mandel router: use two input photons each in a superposition of \u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 and a static chip demultiplexer + beam\u2010splitters to switch interference patterns, enabling entanglement routing based on HOM signature.  \n 3) A frequency\u2010bin parity\u2010check network: three qubits in \u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 enter a chip that measures their parity (XOR) via ancilla pairs, yielding a three-party postselected GHZ-type parity outcome.  \nStep 2: Quick novelty & Pytheus fit:\n 1) The quantum\u2010switch idea is genuinely new: it elevates entanglement swapping to an indefinite\u2010order primitive using only static wavelength\u2010dependent routing\u2014fully expressible in Pytheus\u2019s abstract linear-optics + pair\u2010sources + detectors model, no feedback needed.  \n 2) The HOM router is interesting but is essentially a wavelength-multiplexed beam splitter\u2014less network\u2010primitive depth.  \n 3) The parity-check network is a GHZ variant; similar ensembles exist.  \nStep 3: Select idea 1.\nStep 4: Novelty\u2014this is the first passive, on-chip proposal for indefinite-order entanglement swapping controlled by a superposition of polariton wavelengths, turning entanglement-swapping into a higher-order quantum network primitive.  \nStep 5: Feasibility\u2014Pytheus can optimize probabilistic Bell-pair sources (for channels AB and BC), a single-photon emitter (control in \u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082), a static linear interferometer with wavelength-selective couplers, and number-resolving detectors. All fit its abstract framework with no cavities or active feed-forward.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of a passive, wavelength-controlled \u201cquantum switch\u201d entanglement\u2010swapping router on an integrated photonic circuit. Instead of a fixed swap, the network performs two Bell\u2010measurements (BSMs) in superposition of orders\u2014either swap AB then BC or BC then AB\u2014based on the polariton\u2010wavelength of a single control photon. When the control photon is prepared in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements a coherent superposition of the two swap orders, realizing indefinite\u2010order entanglement distribution between endpoints A and C.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 (for A\u2013B) \u2192 modes [0,1]\n   \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 (for B\u2013C) \u2192 modes [2,3]\n   \u2022 Single\u2010photon control E (wavelength qubit \u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082) \u2192 mode [4]\n\n                    \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optical interferometer  \n  (wavelength\u2010demultiplexer + mesh of beam splitters, optimized by Pytheus)  \n                    \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nBehavior:\n \u2022 Control in \u03bb\u2081 routes the ancilla modes so that BSM\u2081 (between modes 1&2) occurs first, swapping entanglement from AB to AC.  \n \u2022 Control in \u03bb\u2082 routes so that BSM\u2082 (between modes 0&3) occurs first, swapping to BC.  \n \u2022 Control in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2 yields a coherent superposition of these two swap orders, verified by distinct multi-click heralding patterns.  \n\nPytheus config hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled quantum-switch entanglement swap.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (control emitter at [4])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two heralding\u2010click sets for the two swap outcomes, plus their coherent superposition signature.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it matters & generalizes:\n1) Elevates entanglement swapping to a genuinely higher-order network primitive\u2014indefinite causal order\u2014without active switching.  \n2) Demonstrates polariton\u2010wavelength as a control knob in integrated photonic routers.  \n3) Blueprint for scaling: add more swap stations and wavelengths to create superposition of arbitrary network orders.  \n4) Fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract optimization: only static linear optics, pair sources, one single photon emitter, and number-resolving detectors."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum-Controlled Time-Bin Basis Entanglement Swapping in the Telecom Band\n\nAbstract: We realize a basis-controlled entanglement swapping protocol for telecom-band time-bin qubits by preparing a single-photon control qubit in the superposition (|early\u232a+e^{i\u03c6}|late\u232a) to route two SPDC-generated Bell pairs between nodes A\u2013R and R\u2013C into either a Z-basis (M_Z) or an X-basis (M_X) Bell-swap module. Heralding coincidences in M_Z versus M_X project the target remote nodes A and C onto \u03a6\u207a_Z or \u03a6\u207a_X respectively, and by scanning \u03c6 and performing two-qubit tomography we observe high-visibility fringes certifying a coherent superposition of distinct Bell-state swap bases beyond ordinary swapping or switching.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear-Optical Quantum Perceptron Activation Gate\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a measurement-induced non-linear \u201cquantum perceptron\u201d gate in a fully passive linear-optical network by combining two unknown photonic qubit inputs with Bell-pair ancillas and post-selection heralding. The target is a single output qubit at node 2 whose probability of measuring |1\u27e9 realizes a tunable threshold (or sigmoid) function f(w\u2081\u00b7x\u2081 + w\u2082\u00b7x\u2082), providing a genuine non-unitary activation primitive for photonic quantum machine learning.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).  Conditioned on one of the six generalized Bell outcomes, this linear-optics and number-resolving detection scheme heralds the target qubit\u2013qutrit Bell state \u201600\u27e9+ei\u03c6\u201612\u27e9/\u221a2 across the two distinct Hilbert spaces without feedback, hyper-entanglement, or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Square-Network Bell Test via Wavefront\u2010Shaped Nanophotonic Resonator Analyzers\n\nAbstract: We propose a fully static four\u2010node cycle experiment (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013A) that employs four independent entangled photon\u2010pair sources and two 4\u00d74 multiport Bell\u2013state analyzers implemented by wavefront shaping of nanophotonic resonator arrays at nodes B and D, while nodes A and C perform local single\u2010photon measurements. By correlating the joint Bell outcomes at B and D with the local measurement results at A and C, this configuration realizes the target \u201cBell_test_stat\u201d square\u2010network Bell inequality, constituting the first photonic demonstration of nonlocal correlations around a cycle without feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose as a target the design of a complete 4-dimensional Bell\u2010basis analyzer for two photonic qudits encoded in four discrete \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d modes, implemented in an integrated linear photonic circuit. Rather than generating a state, the goal is a measurement network that, upon detection clicks, unambiguously projects any incoming pair of 4-mode qudits onto which one of the 16 maximally entangled Bell states they occupied.  \n\nVisualization of the general structure (modes 0\u20133 are qudit A, 4\u20137 are qudit B; modes 8\u201311 are ancilla single-photon sources):  \n emitters: [8] [9] [10] [11]  \n        \u2193  \n integrated linear network (to be optimized)  \n        \u2193  \n detectors: 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 anc. det. 9 anc. det. 10 anc. det. 11 anc. det.  \n\nKey configuration elements for pytheus:\n\u2022 description: \u201c4d Bell\u2010state analyzer for wavelength\u2010encoded qudits.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 4 (single_emitters at nodes 8\u201311)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [8,9,10,11]  \n\u2022 target_quantum: the 16 four-mode \u201cBell\u201d patterns (e.g. strings \u201800, 11, 22, \u2026 33\u2019 but generalized to all 16 combinations)  \n\u2022 number_resolving: True  \n\u2022 removed_connections: [] (no forbidden links; all couplings allowed)  \n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n\u2022 Demonstrates the first on-chip complete Bell measurement in dimension d>2, using \u201cwavelength\u201d modes as an abstract stand-in for polariton wavelengths.  \n\u2022 Once found, the same circuit architecture can be generalized to d=5,6,\u2026 or to multiplexed repeater nodes.  \n\u2022 Enables high-dimensional entanglement swapping and teleportation protocols in integrated photonics, probing fundamental limits of linear-optical Bell measurements.  \n\u2022 Opens a path toward wavelength-multiplexed quantum routers and repeaters without relying on cavities or dynamic feedback.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While a 4-dimensional Bell-state analyzer is an important target, this proposal closely mirrors the ensemble\u2019s \u201cPassive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts.\u201d Both seek a static linear-optical circuit with ancilla photons and number-resolving detectors to unambiguously discriminate all 16 ququart Bell states. Because the core novelty (a complete d=4 Bell analyzer in integrated photonics) has already been captured, this idea is not sufficiently distinct or groundbreaking for a PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The concept duplicates the ensemble\u2019s passive 4D Bell-state analyzer for ququarts. To be novel, you must introduce fundamentally new ingredients\u2014e.g. non-linear interactions, topological or adaptive elements, or a measurement primitive beyond straightforward linear-optical generalization to higher d.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose as a target the design of a wavelength-division-multiplexed entanglement-swapping station on an integrated photonic circuit. The task is not to generate a particular state but to realize a passive linear-optical network that, when two independent Bell-pair sources (one at polariton-wavelength \u03bb\u2081, one at allowed within the chip)  \n\nWhy this is valuable:\n1) Introduces polariton-wavelength multiplexing into multi-channel entanglement swapping, a new primitive for on-chip quantum routers.  \n2) Cuts ancilla resources by 50% via channel multiplexing\u2014vital for scalable repeaters.  \n3) Once the 2-channel design is found, it generalizes to N channels: a family of resource-efficient WDM entanglement routers.  \n4) Directly amenable to pytheus\u2019s abstraction: only linear optics, pair sources, single photons, and photon\u2010number detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This two-channel wavelength-multiplexed swap is essentially a trivial replication of known multiplexing tricks (cf. the ensemble\u2019s \u201cTemporal-Mode Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping with Single Ancilla\u201d) but in the frequency domain. It offers no genuinely new measurement primitive or nontrivial network effect\u2014just parallel copies of a standard entanglement swap.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal merely ported time-bin multiplexing to wavelength channels without adding a fundamentally new ingredient. To be PRL-worthy, you\u2019ll need a nontrivial twist\u2014e.g. cross-channel interference effects, a joint multi-frequency Bell projection, topological protection, adaptive or nonlinear elements, or an indefinite\u2010order routing primitive that goes beyond parallelizing standard swaps.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose as a target the design of a complete frequency\u2010bin Bell\u2010state analyzer on an integrated photonic circuit, using polariton\u2010wavelength modes as the discrete 2-level encoding.  \n \nGoal (network, not state generation): Take two qubits, each encoded into a photon occupying either of two discrete polariton\u2010wavelength bins (\u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) in spatial modes A and B. The goal is to reproduce the nonclassical correlation pattern characteristic of the triangle network (violating any classical \u201cbilocal\u201d hidden\u2010variable bound) purely via passive optics and heralding\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no state generation.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n  emitters:\n    \u2022 Pair source This is a core quantum-network primitive (used in fingerprinting, entanglement verification, routing), now in the polariton-wavelength domain and on-chip.\n\nGeneral structure (modes numbered 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; Instead of generating a fixed entangled state, the chip should perform one of two entanglement-swapping operations\u2014between remote nodes A&C or between B&D\u2014based solely on the polariton-wavelength of a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and if that photon is prepared in a superposition of the two wavelengths, the router will implement a coherent superposition of the two detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   D2 D3   D4 D5\n   (A  C)  (B  D)  (ctrl anc)\n\nOperation & targets:\n \u2022 If the control photon is in wavelength \u03bb\u2081, the linear network should route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the coherent sum of those two orderings, yielding a superposed entanglement link.  \n \u2022 The chip\u2019s success is heralded by distinct 3-click patterns: one signature for \u201cA\u2013C swapped,\u201d another for \u201cB\u2013D swapped,\u201d each correlated with which control-ancilla detector clicked.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nBehavior:\n \u2022 Control in \u03bb\u2081 routes the ancilla modes so that BSM\u2081 (between modes 1&2) occurs first, swapping entanglement from AB to AC.  \n \u2022 Control in \u03bb\u2082 routes so that BSM\u2082 (between modes 0&3) occurs first, swapping to BC.  \n \u2022 Control in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2 yields a coherent superposition of these two swap orders, verified by distinct multi-click heralding patterns.  \n\nPytheus config hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled quantum-switch entanglement swap.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (control emitter at [4])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two heralding\u2010click sets for the two swap outcomes, plus their coherent superposition signature.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it matters & generalizes:\n1) Elevates entanglement swapping to a genuinely higher-order network primitive\u2014indefinite causal order\u2014without active switching.  \n2) Demonstrates polariton\u2010wavelength as a control knob in integrated photonic routers.  \n3) Blueprint for scaling: add more swap stations and wavelengths to create superposition of arbitrary network orders. proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed wavelength\u2010controlled, indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swap router is essentially a re\u2010encoding of the ensemble\u2019s \u201cImplementing an Entanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d (and similar Quantum SWITCH protocols) into polariton\u2010wavelength modes, offering no new measurement primitive or network effect beyond existing controlled\u2010swap and indefinite\u2010order swap schemes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicate of the entanglement\u2010switch/quantum\u2010switch primitive lacks genuine novelty. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. Pytheus can handle two Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancilla sources, a linear network, and number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n  3) The chained teleportation is just repeating known qubit teleportation twice in series; less novel.\n Step 3: Pick idea\u20092.\n Step 4: This idea is novel because it fuses polariton\u2010wavelength division multiplexing with entanglement\u2010swapping, demonstrating simultaneous passive swapping of two wavelength\u2010tagged Bell pairs in one integrated chip, halving the usual ancilla overhead. Nobody has designed a multi\u2010channel entanglement router that leverages wavelength DOFs for resource compression in linear optics.  \n Step 5: It is feasible in the pytheus framework because it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources (one at \u03bb\u2081, one at \u03bb\u2082)  \n    \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters as ancilla  \n    \u2022 A static linear interferometer (the integrated circuit)  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding  \n  All of these elements map directly onto pytheus\u2019s abstract network\u2010and\u2010detector model.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a target the design of a wavelength-division-multiplexed entanglement-swapping station on an integrated photonic circuit. two single emitters 4&5 provide extra photons.  \n \u2022 Linear network mixes all six modes so that each Bell state of (0,1) and one ancilla photon yields a unique 4-click signature across D0\u2013D7.  \n \nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency\u2010bin Bell\u2010state analyzer on chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 3 (one pair source, two single_emitters: [2,3] for the pair, [4] and [5] for singles)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4,5]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the set of 4 distinct 6-click patterns (one for each Bell state) across detectors D0\u2026D7  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it matters:\n 1) Introduces genuine cross\u2010wavelength interference on chip\u2014mixing \u03bb\u2081 and \u03bb\u2082 modes to perform a nontrivial multi-frequency Bell measurement.  \n 2) Achieves deterministic (postselected) discrimination of all four frequency\u2010bin Bell states, a primitive missing in both bulk and integrated photonics.  \n 3) Opens up frequency\u2010multiplexed entanglement swapping and teleportation protocols on scalable circuits.  \n 4) Fully compatible with pytheus\u2019s abstract-mode, linear-optics, ancilla\u2010and-detector framework\u2014no feedback or non-linear materials needed.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Full Bell analysis with ancilla photons in linear optics is a known protocol and the ensemble already covers its 4D frequency-mode extension; Each node receives two modes at two different wavelengths (one from each of two sources), applies a fixed linear\u2010optic transformation (to be optimized), and performs photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection. The goal is to reproduce the nonclassical correlation pattern characteristic of the triangle network (violating any classical \u201cbilocal\u201d hidden\u2010variable bound) purely via passive optics and heralding\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no state generation.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; The goal is not to generate a new state but to implement the measurement that projects any two unknown qubits (each encoded into a single photon occupying \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) onto the symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces, thereby revealing if they are identical or not. This is a core quantum-network primitive (used in fingerprinting, entanglement verification, routing), now in the polariton-wavelength domain and on-chip.\n\nGeneral structure (modes numbered 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit A \u2192 mode 0,1  (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit B \u2192 mode 2,3  (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Ancilla Bell pair \u2192 mode 4,5\n\n             \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optical circuit (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nInterpretation:\n \u2022 Inputs: modes 0&1 carry qubit A; modes 2&3 carry qubit B; modes 4&5 an ancilla Bell pair |00>+|11> (abstract).  \n \u2022 The linear network mixes all six modes so that a particular pattern of 4 or 6 clicks unambiguously heralds the symmetric vs. antisymmetric projection of A\u2297B.  \n \u2022 Detector patterns (e.g. double clicks in certain pairs) signal \u201cidentical\u201d (symmetric) or \u201cdifferent\u201d (antisymmetric).\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency-bin SWAP-test on integrated photonic chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1  (one probabilistic Bell pair at modes [4,5])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the two projector outcomes\u2014\u201csymmetric\u201d and \u201cantisymmetric\u201d\u2014encoded as distinct detector-click patterns across D0\u2026D5.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable and expandable:\n 1) First on-chip SWAP test in the frequency/polariton-wavelength domain.  \n 2) A primitive for multiplexed entanglement verification, quantum fingerprinting, error-diagnosis in wavelength-division networks.  \n 3) Immediately generalizable to d-dimensional \u201cSWAP tests\u201d for qudits in more wavelengths.  \n 4) Entirely within pytheus\u2019s toolkit: pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no forbidden cavities or active feed-forward.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel at the PRL level, you need to go beyond a direct port of the standard SWAP test to another encoding. final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a pytheus target the design of an integrated-photonic SWAP-test circuit for two frequency-bin (polariton-wavelength) qubits. Rather than generating new states, the goal is a passive linear-optical network that, when two unknown qubits (each a single photon in either \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) plus one ancilla Bell pair are injected, projects the joint inputs onto the symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces\u2014i.e. it implements the SWAP-test measurement, a fundamental quantum-network primitive for fingerprinting and entanglement verification.\n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit A \u2192 modes [0,1] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Unknown qubit B \u2192 modes [2,3] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Ancilla Bell pair \u2192 modes [4,5]  \n\n             \u2193\n static integrated linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nMapping & operation:\n \u2022 Inputs in modes 0/1 and 2/3 carry the two unknown frequency-bin qubits.  \n \u2022 The ancilla Bell pair in 4/5 supplies the entanglement resource.  \n \u2022 The optimized network mixes all six modes so that symmetric inputs (qubits equal) yield one unique detector-click signature, while antisymmetric inputs (qubits different) yield a different signature.  \n \u2022 By postselecting on these distinct click patterns, one can unambiguously decide \u201cidentical\u201d vs. \u201cdifferent\u201d for the two qubits.\n\nSuggested pytheus config hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cIntegrated-photonic SWAP-test for frequency-bin qubits.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (one Bell-pair source at [4,5])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two projector outcomes (symmetric vs. antisymmetric), encoded as distinct detector patterns across D0\u2026D5.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable & extensible:\n 1) First demonstration of the SWAP-test measurement in the polariton-wavelength DOF on an integrated chip.  \n 2) A key building block for quantum fingerprinting, entanglement routing and verification in wavelength-division networks.  \n 3) Once found, generalizes to higher-dimensional SWAP-tests (d>2) or parallel multi-qubit SWAP-tests on many wavelength channels.  \n 4) Fully within pytheus\u2019s abstraction: pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback control or non-linear elements needed.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The SWAP\u2010test is a well\u2010known linear\u2010optical primitive (e.g. the ensemble\u2019s six\u2010photon SWAP\u2010test and parallel qudit SWAP\u2010networks).     "output": "Here is a concrete Pytheus\u2010compatible target that (1) combines polariton-wavelength encoding with an integrated linear-optic circuit and (2) goes beyond a single swap by realising entanglement percolation on a 4\u2010node cycle (ring) network.\n\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------  \n\u201c4-node cycle entanglement-percolation via polariton-wavelength multiplexing\u201d\n\nexplanation:\n  We arrange four probabilistic Bell-pair sources on a single integrated chip, each source emitting into one pair of abstract modes that we label by their \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d (\u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082, \u03bb\u2083, \u03bb\u2084).  \n  The eight photons are then routed through a static mesh of directional couplers (the integrated circuit) that implements local Bell-measurements (BSMs) on each of the four adjacent links of the cycle.  \n  By heralding on detector clicks at those four BSM locations, entanglement \u201cpercolates\u201d around the ring: a successful pattern of three out of four BSMs will leave the two remaining nodes sharing entanglement, despite the lack of direct pair-source between them.  \n  This is a fundamental multi-node quantum-network primitive\u2014studying how network topology and wavelength-multiplexed links can distribute entanglement\u2014generalizable to N-gons and beyond.\n\nvisualization (modes 0\u20267 in; detectors D0\u2026D7 out):\n   sources:  [pair@\u03bb\u2081]\u21920,1   [pair@\u03bb\u2082]\u21922,3   [pair@\u03bb\u2083]\u21924,5   [pair@\u03bb\u2084]\u21926,7  \n                \u2193                     \u2193  \n           integrated 4\u00d74 coupler\u2013mesh  \n                \u2193                     \u2193  \n   detectors:  D0 D1  D2 D3  D4 D5  D6 D7  \n   BSMs heralded on clicks at (1,2), (3,4), (5,6), (7,0)\n\nconfig:\n  description: \"4-node cycle entanglement percolation via polariton-wavelength multiplexing\"\n  foldername: \"cycle4-polw\"\n  edges_tried: 40\n  ftol: 1e-6\n  loss_func: \"percolation\"        # custom metric rewarding successful percolation patterns\n  num_anc: 0                      # no extra single-photon ancilla beyond the four pair sources\n  num_pre: 1\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\"\n  samples: 20\n  in_nodes: []                    # all inputs are from the four pair sources\n  out_nodes: []                   # all outputs go to the eight detectors\n  thresholds: [0.2]               # minimum heralding probability per BSM\n  heralding_out: [[1,2],[3,4],[5,6],[7,0]]  \n  single_emitters: []\n  tries_per_edge: 10\n  removed_connections: []         # all couplings allowed; circuit must choose the optimal routing\n  number_resolving: True\n\nWhy this is compelling and generalizable:\n  \u2022 Demonstrates on-chip entanglement percolation in a cycle topology using only static linear optics and wavelength-multiplexed links.  \n  \u2022 Uses polariton-wavelength as an abstract encoding\u2014physically implementable via different cavity detunings or waveguide dimensions\u2014but Pytheus treats them simply as distinct modes.  \n  \u2022 Once solved, the same design can be scaled to N-node rings, lattices or random graphs, exploring network-theoretic questions in entanglement distribution.  \n  \u2022 Stays entirely within Pytheus\u2019s scope: probabilistic pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities, no non-linear elements."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. Pytheus can handle two Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancilla sources, a linear network, and number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n  3) The chained teleportation is just repeating known qubit teleportation twice in series; less novel.\n Step 3: Pick idea\u20092.\n Step 4: This idea is novel because it fuses polariton\u2010wavelength division multiplexing with entanglement\u2010swapping, demonstrating simultaneous passive swapping of two wavelength\u2010tagged Bell pairs in one integrated chip, halving the usual ancilla overhead. Nobody has designed a multi\u2010channel entanglement router that leverages wavelength DOFs for resource compression in linear optics.  \n Step 5: It is feasible in the pytheus framework because it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources (one at \u03bb\u2081, one at \u03bb\u2082)  \n    \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters as ancilla  \n    \u2022 A static linear interferometer (the integrated circuit)  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding  \n  All of these elements map directly onto pytheus\u2019s abstract network\u2010and\u2010detector model.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a target the design of a wavelength-division-multiplexed entanglement-swapping station on an integrated photonic circuit. two single emitters 4&5 provide extra photons.  \n \u2022 Linear network mixes all six modes so that each Bell state of (0,1) and one ancilla photon yields a unique 4-click signature across D0\u2013D7.  \n \nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency\u2010bin Bell\u2010state analyzer on chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 3 (one pair source, two single_emitters: [2,3] for the pair, [4] and [5] for singles)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4,5]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the set of 4 distinct 6-click patterns (one for each Bell state) across detectors D0\u2026D7  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it matters:\n 1) Introduces genuine cross\u2010wavelength interference on chip\u2014mixing \u03bb\u2081 and \u03bb\u2082 modes to perform a nontrivial multi-frequency Bell measurement.  \n 2) Achieves deterministic (postselected) discrimination of all four frequency\u2010bin Bell states, a primitive missing in both bulk and integrated photonics.  \n 3) Opens up frequency\u2010multiplexed entanglement swapping and teleportation protocols on scalable circuits.  \n 4) Fully compatible with pytheus\u2019s abstract-mode, linear-optics, ancilla\u2010and-detector framework\u2014no feedback or non-linear materials needed.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Full Bell analysis with ancilla photons in linear optics is a known protocol and the ensemble already covers its 4D frequency-mode extension; Each node receives two modes at two different wavelengths (one from each of two sources), applies a fixed linear\u2010optic transformation (to be optimized), and performs photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection. The goal is to reproduce the nonclassical correlation pattern characteristic of the triangle network (violating any classical \u201cbilocal\u201d hidden\u2010variable bound) purely via passive optics and heralding\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no state generation.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; The goal is not to generate a new state but to implement the measurement that projects any two unknown qubits (each encoded into a single photon occupying \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) onto the symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces, thereby revealing if they are identical or not. This is a core quantum-network primitive (used in fingerprinting, entanglement verification, routing), now in the polariton-wavelength domain and on-chip.\n\nGeneral structure (modes numbered 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit A \u2192 mode 0,1  (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit B \u2192 mode 2,3  (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Ancilla Bell pair \u2192 mode 4,5\n\n             \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optical circuit (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nInterpretation:\n \u2022 Inputs: modes 0&1 carry qubit A; modes 2&3 carry qubit B; modes 4&5 an ancilla Bell pair |00>+|11> (abstract).  \n \u2022 The linear network mixes all six modes so that a particular pattern of 4 or 6 clicks unambiguously heralds the symmetric vs. antisymmetric projection of A\u2297B.  \n \u2022 Detector patterns (e.g. double clicks in certain pairs) signal \u201cidentical\u201d (symmetric) or \u201cdifferent\u201d (antisymmetric).\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency-bin SWAP-test on integrated photonic chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1  (one probabilistic Bell pair at modes [4,5])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the two projector outcomes\u2014\u201csymmetric\u201d and \u201cantisymmetric\u201d\u2014encoded as distinct detector-click patterns across D0\u2026D5.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable and expandable:\n 1) First on-chip SWAP test in the frequency/polariton-wavelength domain.  \n 2) A primitive for multiplexed entanglement verification, quantum fingerprinting, error-diagnosis in wavelength-division networks.  \n 3) Immediately generalizable to d-dimensional \u201cSWAP tests\u201d for qudits in more wavelengths.  \n 4) Entirely within pytheus\u2019s toolkit: pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no forbidden cavities or active feed-forward.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel at the PRL level, you need to go beyond a direct port of the standard SWAP test to another encoding. final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a pytheus target the design of an integrated-photonic SWAP-test circuit for two frequency-bin (polariton-wavelength) qubits. Rather than generating new states, the goal is a passive linear-optical network that, when two unknown qubits (each a single photon in either \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) plus one ancilla Bell pair are injected, projects the joint inputs onto the symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces\u2014i.e. it implements the SWAP-test measurement, a fundamental quantum-network primitive for fingerprinting and entanglement verification.\n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit A \u2192 modes [0,1] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Unknown qubit B \u2192 modes [2,3] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Ancilla Bell pair \u2192 modes [4,5]  \n\n             \u2193\n static integrated linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nMapping & operation:\n \u2022 Inputs in modes 0/1 and 2/3 carry the two unknown frequency-bin qubits.  \n \u2022 The ancilla Bell pair in 4/5 supplies the entanglement resource.  \n \u2022 The optimized network mixes all six modes so that symmetric inputs (qubits equal) yield one unique detector-click signature, while antisymmetric inputs (qubits different) yield a different signature.  \n \u2022 By postselecting on these distinct click patterns, one can unambiguously decide \u201cidentical\u201d vs. \u201cdifferent\u201d for the two qubits.\n\nSuggested pytheus config hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cIntegrated-photonic SWAP-test for frequency-bin qubits.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (one Bell-pair source at [4,5])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two projector outcomes (symmetric vs. antisymmetric), encoded as distinct detector patterns across D0\u2026D5.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable & extensible:\n 1) First demonstration of the SWAP-test measurement in the polariton-wavelength DOF on an integrated chip.  \n 2) A key building block for quantum fingerprinting, entanglement routing and verification in wavelength-division networks.  \n 3) Once found, generalizes to higher-dimensional SWAP-tests (d>2) or parallel multi-qubit SWAP-tests on many wavelength channels.  \n 4) Fully within pytheus\u2019s abstraction: pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback control or non-linear elements needed.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The SWAP\u2010test is a well\u2010known linear\u2010optical primitive (e.g. the ensemble\u2019s six\u2010photon SWAP\u2010test and parallel qudit SWAP\u2010networks).     "output": "We propose as a Pytheus target the first **on\u2010chip, passive entanglement\u2010purification circuit for two frequency\u2010bin qubit pairs** (encoded in two discrete polariton wavelengths \u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082) in an integrated photonic chip. Instead of generating a new state, the chip implements the bilateral parity\u2010check step of the Bennett purification protocol: two noisy Bell\u2010pairs (A\u2081\u2013B\u2081 and A\u2082\u2013B\u2082) are interfered locally in wavelength\u2010selective beam splitter meshes, and a coincident \u201ceven\u2010even\u201d click pattern at the two measurement ports heralds a single purified entangled qubit pair between the remaining two photonic modes.\n\n\u2500\u2500\u2500  \nGeneral structure (modes numbered 0\u20265, top\u2192bottom; detectors left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]  (entangles A\u2081\u2013B\u2081 in \u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]  (entangles A\u2082\u2013B\u2082 in \u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n                \u2193  \n integrated wavelength\u2010demultiplexer + 50/50 beam\u2010splitter mesh (static circuit to be optimized by Pytheus)  \n                \u2193  \n detectors (number\u2010resolving):  \n   D0   D1    D2   D3    D4   D5  \n   (A\u2081\u2019  A\u2082\u2019) (B\u2081\u2019  B\u2082\u2019) (\u2297   \u2297)  \n\n  \u2013 D0/D1 register parity at Alice\u2019s side (mixing modes 0&2).  \n  \u2013 D2/D3 register parity at Bob\u2019s side   (mixing modes 1&3).  \n  \u2013 D4/D5 are the two surviving modes (A\u2082\u2019,B\u2082\u2019) that become the purified pair when D0/D1 and D2/D3 both click in the \u201ceven\u201d port.  \n\n\u2500\u2500\u2500  \nPytheus configuration hints:  \n description: \u201cIntegrated entanglement\u2010purification for frequency\u2010bin qubits.\u201d  \n pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n in_nodes: [0,1,2,3]  \n out_nodes: [4,5]  \n num_anc: 0  \n single_emitters: []  \n number_resolving: True  \n removed_connections: []  \n target_quantum: postselect on the 4\u2010click pattern \u201cD0_even & D1_even & D2_even & D3_even\u201d \u2192 herald purified entangled pair in modes [4,5].  \n\n\u2500\u2500\u2500  \nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:  \n 1) **First passive on\u2010chip purification** of frequency\u2010bin entanglement, combining polariton\u2010wavelength encoding with integrated photonics.  \n 2) A **key network primitive** beyond swapping/teleportation: entanglement distillation, vital for real\u2010world quantum repeaters in wavelength\u2010division multiplexed architectures.  \n 3) **Resource\u2010efficient** (no feedback, no additional ancilla) and fully passive\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit of pair sources, linear interferometers, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n 4) Opens a family of circuits: chain multiple purification stages, extend to d\u2010level frequency bins, or interleave swapping+purification on one chip.  \n\nThis should give the Expert a crisp, novel, and Pytheus\u2010compatible target that leverages both polariton\u2010wavelength multiplexing and integrated photonic circuits for a foundational quantum\u2010network operation."
}

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. Pytheus can handle two Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancilla sources, a linear network, and number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n  3) The chained teleportation is just repeating known qubit teleportation twice in series; less novel.\n Step 3: Pick idea\u20092.\n Step 4: This idea is novel because it fuses polariton\u2010wavelength division multiplexing with entanglement\u2010swapping, demonstrating simultaneous passive swapping of two wavelength\u2010tagged Bell pairs in one integrated chip, halving the usual ancilla overhead. Nobody has designed a multi\u2010channel entanglement router that leverages wavelength DOFs for resource compression in linear optics.  \n Step 5: It is feasible in the pytheus framework because it only requires:\n    \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources (one at \u03bb\u2081, one at \u03bb\u2082)  \n    \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters as ancilla  \n    \u2022 A static linear interferometer (the integrated circuit)  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding  \n  All of these elements map directly onto pytheus\u2019s abstract network\u2010and\u2010detector model.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a target the design of a wavelength-division-multiplexed entanglement-swapping station on an integrated photonic circuit. two single emitters 4&5 provide extra photons.  \n \u2022 Linear network mixes all six modes so that each Bell state of (0,1) and one ancilla photon yields a unique 4-click signature across D0\u2013D7.  \n \nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency\u2010bin Bell\u2010state analyzer on chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 3 (one pair source, two single_emitters: [2,3] for the pair, [4] and [5] for singles)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4,5]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the set of 4 distinct 6-click patterns (one for each Bell state) across detectors D0\u2026D7  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it matters:\n 1) Introduces genuine cross\u2010wavelength interference on chip\u2014mixing \u03bb\u2081 and \u03bb\u2082 modes to perform a nontrivial multi-frequency Bell measurement.  \n 2) Achieves deterministic (postselected) discrimination of all four frequency\u2010bin Bell states, a primitive missing in both bulk and integrated photonics.  \n 3) Opens up frequency\u2010multiplexed entanglement swapping and teleportation protocols on scalable circuits.  \n 4) Fully compatible with pytheus\u2019s abstract-mode, linear-optics, ancilla\u2010and-detector framework\u2014no feedback or non-linear materials needed.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Full Bell analysis with ancilla photons in linear optics is a known protocol and the ensemble already covers its 4D frequency-mode extension; Each node receives two modes at two different wavelengths (one from each of two sources), applies a fixed linear\u2010optic transformation (to be optimized), and performs photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection. The goal is to reproduce the nonclassical correlation pattern characteristic of the triangle network (violating any classical \u201cbilocal\u201d hidden\u2010variable bound) purely via passive optics and heralding\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no state generation.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; The goal is not to generate a new state but to implement the measurement that projects any two unknown qubits (each encoded into a single photon occupying \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) onto the symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces, thereby revealing if they are identical or not. This is a core quantum-network primitive (used in fingerprinting, entanglement verification, routing), now in the polariton-wavelength domain and on-chip.\n\nGeneral structure (modes numbered 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit A \u2192 mode 0,1  (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit B \u2192 mode 2,3  (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Ancilla Bell pair \u2192 mode 4,5\n\n             \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optical circuit (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nInterpretation:\n \u2022 Inputs: modes 0&1 carry qubit A; modes 2&3 carry qubit B; modes 4&5 an ancilla Bell pair |00>+|11> (abstract).  \n \u2022 The linear network mixes all six modes so that a particular pattern of 4 or 6 clicks unambiguously heralds the symmetric vs. antisymmetric projection of A\u2297B.  \n \u2022 Detector patterns (e.g. double clicks in certain pairs) signal \u201cidentical\u201d (symmetric) or \u201cdifferent\u201d (antisymmetric).\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency-bin SWAP-test on integrated photonic chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1  (one probabilistic Bell pair at modes [4,5])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the two projector outcomes\u2014\u201csymmetric\u201d and \u201cantisymmetric\u201d\u2014encoded as distinct detector-click patterns across D0\u2026D5.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable and expandable:\n 1) First on-chip SWAP test in the frequency/polariton-wavelength domain.  \n 2) A primitive for multiplexed entanglement verification, quantum fingerprinting, error-diagnosis in wavelength-division networks.  \n 3) Immediately generalizable to d-dimensional \u201cSWAP tests\u201d for qudits in more wavelengths.  \n 4) Entirely within pytheus\u2019s toolkit: pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no forbidden cavities or active feed-forward.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel at the PRL level, you need to go beyond a direct port of the standard SWAP test to another encoding. final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a pytheus target the design of an integrated-photonic SWAP-test circuit for two frequency-bin (polariton-wavelength) qubits. Rather than generating new states, the goal is a passive linear-optical network that, when two unknown qubits (each a single photon in either \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) plus one ancilla Bell pair are injected, projects the joint inputs onto the symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces\u2014i.e. it implements the SWAP-test measurement, a fundamental quantum-network primitive for fingerprinting and entanglement verification.\n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit A \u2192 modes [0,1] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Unknown qubit B \u2192 modes [2,3] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Ancilla Bell pair \u2192 modes [4,5]  \n\n             \u2193\n static integrated linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nMapping & operation:\n \u2022 Inputs in modes 0/1 and 2/3 carry the two unknown frequency-bin qubits.  \n \u2022 The ancilla Bell pair in 4/5 supplies the entanglement resource.  \n \u2022 The optimized network mixes all six modes so that symmetric inputs (qubits equal) yield one unique detector-click signature, while antisymmetric inputs (qubits different) yield a different signature.  \n \u2022 By postselecting on these distinct click patterns, one can unambiguously decide \u201cidentical\u201d vs. \u201cdifferent\u201d for the two qubits.\n\nSuggested pytheus config hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cIntegrated-photonic SWAP-test for frequency-bin qubits.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (one Bell-pair source at [4,5])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two projector outcomes (symmetric vs. antisymmetric), encoded as distinct detector patterns across D0\u2026D5.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable & extensible:\n 1) First demonstration of the SWAP-test measurement in the polariton-wavelength DOF on an integrated chip.  \n 2) A key building block for quantum fingerprinting, entanglement routing and verification in wavelength-division networks.  \n 3) Once found, generalizes to higher-dimensional SWAP-tests (d>2) or parallel multi-qubit SWAP-tests on many wavelength channels.  \n 4) Fully within pytheus\u2019s abstraction: pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback control or non-linear elements needed.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The SWAP\u2010test is a well\u2010known linear\u2010optical primitive (e.g. the ensemble\u2019s six\u2010photon SWAP\u2010test and parallel qudit SWAP\u2010networks). route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the
