    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d and \u201cintegrated photonic circuit\u201d in a genuinely new network primitive (no state generation):\n    1) A 4-level Bell-state analyzer on chip, using four discrete polariton\u2010wavelength bins as a qudit.\n    2) Parallel wavelength-division entanglement swapping in two channels in one static circuit.\n    3) A photonic quantum\u2013network coding \u201cbutterfly\u201d node: one static interferometer that, using a single shared link and polariton-wavelength multiplexing, carries out the two\u2010qubit teleportation network coding protocol\u2014letting two senders exchange qubits over a single physical channel without feedback.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility:\n    1) Too close to existing high-D Bell analyzers.\n    2) Already dismissed as mere parallelization.\n    3) Quantum network coding has never been implemented in integrated photonics with wavelength multiplexing; it is a true extension of entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation to multi\u2010sender multi\u2010receiver scenarios, and maps exactly onto Pytheus\u2019s resources: two pair\u2010sources, static linear\u2010optical mesh, number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities.\n  Step 3: Choose idea\u20093.\n  Step 4: Novelty: This is the first proposal for an on-chip \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum network node that uses polariton wavelength as the multiplexing DOF to implement the quantum network\u2010coding protocol (two simultaneous teleportations over one shared link). It goes beyond point\u2010to\u2010point swapping or teleportation by fusing them into a genuine network\u2010coding primitive.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can optimize exactly this kind of static linear\u2010optical network fed by probabilistic pair\u2010sources and number\u2010resolving detectors. All elements (sources, interferometer, detectors) are within its abstraction; no dynamic feedback or cavities are required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the on\u2010chip implementation of the quantum network\u2010coding \u201cbutterfly\u201d node, realized in an integrated photonic circuit that exploits polariton\u2010wavelength multiplexing. The task is not to generate a fixed state but to carry out the two\u2010qubit teleportation network code\u2014two senders S\u2081 and S\u2082 each hold an unknown qubit encoded in two polariton wavelengths (\u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082). They both inject their photons into a single shared link (a wavelength\u2010division\u2010multiplexed waveguide) plus two local Bell\u2010pair sources. A static integrated circuit then performs the joint Bell\u2010measurements in the correct pattern so that the two qubits emerge at two separate receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082\u2014exactly as in the classical \u201cbutterfly\u201d network code, but now fully quantum.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Pair source A\u2013M \u2192 modes [0,1]\n   \u2022 Pair source B\u2013M \u2192 modes [2,3]\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit S\u2081 \u2192 mode [4] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit S\u2082 \u2192 mode [5] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n\n                   \u2193\n integrated static linear\u2010optical mesh (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors:\n   \u2022 D0,D1 (for BSM of S\u2081 with ancilla A\u2013M)\n   \u2022 D2,D3 (for BSM of S\u2082 with ancilla B\u2013M)\n   \u2022 D4,D5 (heralding pattern that encodes the network\u2010code \u201cXOR\u201d step)\n\nProcedure & targets:\n \u2022 S\u2081\u2019s qubit in mode 4 and one photon of source A\u2013M in mode 1 undergo a Bell\u2010measurement (BM\u2081) if the control of the internal coupler is set to route \u03bb\u2081 pulses.  \n \u2022 S\u2082\u2019s qubit in mode 5 and one photon of source B\u2013M in mode 3 undergo BM\u2082 if the routing is \u03bb\u2082.  \n \u2022 Both BMs share the same physical beamsplitter but are separated in the wavelength domain.  \n \u2022 The detectors D4/D5 record which combination of BSM outcomes occurred\u2014effectively computing the required \u201cXOR\u201d (network code) and heralding two teleported qubits at R\u2081 and R\u2082.  \n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cButterfly quantum network\u2010coding node via wavelength multiplexing.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n \u2022 num_anc: 0 additional ancilla (uses only the two Bell\u2010pair sources)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 input_modes: [4,5] (the two sender qubits)  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 target_operation: simultaneous teleportation of S\u2081\u2192R\u2081 and S\u2082\u2192R\u2082 using one shared interconnect, with herald clicks at D0\u2026D5 encoding the network code.  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s impactful and generalizable:\n 1) First on\u2010chip demonstration of quantum network coding in a genuine \u201cbutterfly\u201d configuration, harnessing polariton\u2010wavelength for multiplexing instead of bulk time\u2010bins or complex switching.  \n 2) Merges entanglement swapping, teleportation, and network coding into a single static circuit\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities\u2014perfectly fitting Pytheus\u2019s toolbox.  \n 3) Lays the foundation for scalable photonic quantum routers and repeaters that compress multiple communication channels into a single waveguide.  \n 4) Directly generalizable to larger network\u2010coding topologies (e.g. multi\u2010sender multicast codes) by adding wavelengths and pair sources in an integrated mesh.\n\nWe believe this target\u2014quantum network coding in a butterfly node via polariton\u2010wavelength multiplexing\u2014will inspire a family of new on\u2010chip quantum network experiments and can be realized by Pytheus\u2019s abstract optimization of linear optics, sources, and detectors."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum-Controlled Time-Bin Basis Entanglement Swapping in the Telecom Band\n\nAbstract: We realize a basis-controlled entanglement swapping protocol for telecom-band time-bin qubits by preparing a single-photon control qubit in the superposition (|early\u232a+e^{i\u03c6}|late\u232a) to route two SPDC-generated Bell pairs between nodes A\u2013R and R\u2013C into either a Z-basis (M_Z) or an X-basis (M_X) Bell-swap module. Heralding coincidences in M_Z versus M_X project the target remote nodes A and C onto \u03a6\u207a_Z or \u03a6\u207a_X respectively, and by scanning \u03c6 and performing two-qubit tomography we observe high-visibility fringes certifying a coherent superposition of distinct Bell-state swap bases beyond ordinary swapping or switching.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear-Optical Quantum Perceptron Activation Gate\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a measurement-induced non-linear \u201cquantum perceptron\u201d gate in a fully passive linear-optical network by combining two unknown photonic qubit inputs with Bell-pair ancillas and post-selection heralding. The target is a single output qubit at node 2 whose probability of measuring |1\u27e9 realizes a tunable threshold (or sigmoid) function f(w\u2081\u00b7x\u2081 + w\u2082\u00b7x\u2082), providing a genuine non-unitary activation primitive for photonic quantum machine learning.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).  Conditioned on one of the six generalized Bell outcomes, this linear-optics and number-resolving detection scheme heralds the target qubit\u2013qutrit Bell state \u201600\u27e9+ei\u03c6\u201612\u27e9/\u221a2 across the two distinct Hilbert spaces without feedback, hyper-entanglement, or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Square-Network Bell Test via Wavefront\u2010Shaped Nanophotonic Resonator Analyzers\n\nAbstract: We propose a fully static four\u2010node cycle experiment (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013A) that employs four independent entangled photon\u2010pair sources and two 4\u00d74 multiport Bell\u2013state analyzers implemented by wavefront shaping of nanophotonic resonator arrays at nodes B and D, while nodes A and C perform local single\u2010photon measurements. By correlating the joint Bell outcomes at B and D with the local measurement results at A and C, this configuration realizes the target \u201cBell_test_stat\u201d square\u2010network Bell inequality, constituting the first photonic demonstration of nonlocal correlations around a cycle without feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Mid\u2010Gap Bell\u2010Pair Extraction in a Dimerized Photonic SSH Repeater Chain  \n\nMini\u2010abstract:  \nWe implement a linear\u2010optical SSH chain of 2M+1 spatial modes using alternating strong (two\u2010pair) and weak (single\u2010pair) photon sources, performing heralded Bell\u2010state measurements at each non\u2010central node.  Post\u2010selection on successful heralds yields a mid\u2010gap Bell pair at the central outputs only in the topological configuration, directly probing the chain\u2019s photonic mid\u2010gap entanglement and demonstrating its robustness against weak\u2010bond failure.Title: Programmable Photonic VQA for GHZ vs W Tripartite Entanglement Certification\n\nMini-abstract: We introduce a PyTheus-designed linear-optical interferometer with tunable beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors, trained via a classical variational loop to classify unknown three-qubit photonic inputs as GHZ-class or W-class states. The experiment explicitly targets eight two-click detection patterns (four at t\u2081, four at t\u2082) on number-resolving, time-tagging detectors, each pattern heralding a successful swap and showcasing a resonator-inspired temporal coupling strategy for resource-efficient quantum network primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Bell-Measurement Node for Loss-Robust Entanglement Swapping\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose replacing the fixed Bell-state analyzer at a quantum repeater node with a small, tunable linear-optics ansatz circuit U(\u03b8) acting on incoming modes B\u2081, B\u2082 and ancilla photons to interpolate between ideal Bell measurements and alternative joint detections. By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Mode\u2010Division\u2010Multiplexed On\u2010Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We propose an integrated\u2010optics node that purifies two probabilistic qutrit photon\u2010pair sources into the target high\u2010fidelity 3-dimensional Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9 by routing Alice\u2019s spatial modes and Bob\u2019s mode\u2010division\u2010multiplexed channels through a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optic parity\u2010check circuit with two ancilla heralding detectors. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose as a target the design of a complete 4-dimensional Bell\u2010basis analyzer for two photonic qudits encoded in four discrete \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d modes, implemented in an integrated linear photonic circuit. The goal is not to generate a new state but to implement the measurement that projects any two unknown qubits (each encoded into a single photon occupying \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) onto the symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces, thereby revealing if they are identical or not. This is a core quantum-network primitive (used in fingerprinting, entanglement verification, routing), now in the polariton-wavelength domain and on-chip.\n\nGeneral structure (modes numbered 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit A \u2192 mode 0,1  (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit B \u2192 mode 2,3  (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Ancilla Bell pair \u2192 mode 4,5\n\n             \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optical circuit (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nInterpretation:\n \u2022 Inputs: modes 0&1 carry qubit A; modes 2&3 carry qubit B; modes 4&5 an ancilla Bell pair |00>+|11> (abstract).  \n \u2022 The linear network mixes all six modes so that a particular pattern of 4 or 6 clicks unambiguously heralds the symmetric vs. antisymmetric projection of A\u2297B.  \n \u2022 Detector patterns (e.g. double clicks in certain pairs) signal \u201cidentical\u201d (symmetric) or \u201cdifferent\u201d (antisymmetric).\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency-bin SWAP-test on integrated photonic chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1  (one probabilistic Bell pair at modes [4,5])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the two projector outcomes\u2014\u201csymmetric\u201d and \u201cantisymmetric\u201d\u2014encoded as distinct detector-click patterns across D0\u2026D5.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable and expandable:\n 1) First on-chip SWAP test in the frequency/polariton-wavelength domain.  \n 2) A primitive for multiplexed entanglement verification, quantum fingerprinting, error-diagnosis in wavelength-division networks.  \n 3) Immediately generalizable to d-dimensional \u201cSWAP tests\u201d for qudits in more wavelengths.  \n 4) Entirely within pytheus\u2019s toolkit: pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no forbidden cavities or active feed-forward.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal is essentially a straightforward linear-optical SWAP test for two frequency-bin qubits using a Bell-pair ancilla\u2014i.e. projecting onto symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces. However, identical ancilla-mediated SWAP-test circuits have already been laid out in the ensemble (e.g. the \u201cDiscrete Quantum-Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP-Test Network\u201d and the \u201cGeneralized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\u201d). This is just a trivial mapping into the polariton-wavelength domain without introducing a new measurement primitive or nontrivial network effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel at the PRL level, you need to go beyond a direct port of the standard SWAP test to another encoding. linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nMapping & operation:\n \u2022 Inputs in modes 0/1 and     "output": "Thought: While framing the qubit-butterfly network\u2010code in polariton\u2010wavelength language is clever, it is essentially the same \u201cbutterfly\u201d entanglement routing primitive already in the ensemble (\u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\u201d) recast with a different encoding. There is no fundamentally new measurement primitive or network effect beyond multiplexing two Bell-measurements into one static circuit.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010graph joint measurement already implements dual-channel entanglement swapping in one shot.     "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"polariton wavelength\" and \"integrated photonic circuit\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Instead of the usual single-ancilla limitation, our network uses two probabilistic Bell-pair sources\u2014one at wavelength \u03bb\u2081, one at \u03bb\u2082\u2014as ancilla resources. \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d and \u201cintegrated photonic circuit\u201d into a new quantum-network primitive (no state-generation):\n   1) A 4-dimensional Bell-analyzer on chip using four polariton wavelengths.  \n   2) A two-channel wavelength-division multiplexed entanglement swap in one static circuit.  \n   3) A wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router: a static integrated circuit that, depending on the polariton-wavelength of a control photon, performs one of two entanglement-swapping operations between remote nodes A\u2013C or B\u2013D, and in superposition it yields a coherent superposition of which link was entangled.\n Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:\n   1) Too close to existing high-D Bell analyzers.  \n   2) Already flagged as parallelization of standard swaps.  \n   3) The controlled-router is genuinely new: it elevates entanglement swapping to a programmable, wavelength-encoded \u201cquantum router\u201d primitive, opening indefinite-order and multiplexed routing, and maps cleanly to Pytheus\u2019s resources (two pair sources, one single photon emitter as control, a static interferometer, number-resolving detectors).\n Step 3: I choose idea 3.\n Step 4: This is novel because no one has proposed a passive, wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router on an integrated chip that can coherently choose (or superpose) which pair of remote nodes to entangle.  \n Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only needs:\n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources (modes 0\u20131 and 2\u20133).  \n   \u2022 One single-photon emitter as a wavelength-encoded control qubit (mode 4).  \n   \u2022 A static linear-optical circuit (to be optimized).  \n   \u2022 Number-resolving detectors at the four node outputs plus two ancilla detectors.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of a wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router in an integrated photonic circuit. Instead of generating a fixed entangled state, the chip should perform one of two entanglement-swapping operations\u2014between remote nodes A&C or between B&D\u2014based solely on the polariton-wavelength of a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and if that photon is prepared in a superposition of the two wavelengths, the router will implement a coherent superposition of the two swap outcomes (a first step toward indefinite-order entanglement distribution). \n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]  (targets A & C)  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]  (targets B & D)  \n   \u2022 Single-photon control E \u2192 mode [4]  (prepared in |\u03bb\u2081\u27e9 or |\u03bb\u2082\u27e9 or their superposition)\n\n                   \u2193\n  integrated linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   D2 D3   D4 D5\n   (A  C)  (B  D)  (ctrl anc)\n\nOperation & targets:\n \u2022 If the control photon is in wavelength \u03bb\u2081, the linear network should route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the coherent sum of those two orderings, yielding a superposed entanglement link.  \n \u2022 The chip\u2019s success is heralded by distinct 3-click patterns: one signature for \u201cA\u2013C swapped,\u201d another for \u201cB\u2013D swapped,\u201d each correlated with which control-ancilla detector clicked.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled entanglement-swap router on chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (control emitter at mode 4)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4]  \n \u2022 pair sources: [[0,1], [2,3]]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two sets of detector-click signatures, one for each swap outcome, plus their coherent superposition.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this is powerful and extensible:\n 1) Introduces the first on-chip, passive quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength as a control qubit to choose and even superpose which remote link is entangled.  \n 2) Lays groundwork for indefinite-order entanglement distribution and multi-channel routing by simply adding more wavelengths and sources.  \n 3) Fully matches Pytheus\u2019s abstract model\u2014probabilistic pair sources, a single-photon emitter, a static interferometer, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014without requiring feedback or cavities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates similar ensembles exist.  \nStep 3: Select idea 1.\nStep 4: Novelty\u2014this is the first passive, on-chip proposal for indefinite-order entanglement swapping controlled by a superposition of polariton wavelengths, turning entanglement-swapping into a higher-order quantum network primitive.  \nStep 5: Feasibility\u2014Pytheus can optimize probabilistic Bell-pair sources (for channels AB and BC), a single-photon emitter (control in \u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082), a static linear interferometer with wavelength-selective couplers, and number-resolving detectors. Instead of a fixed swap, the network performs two Bell\u2010measurements (BSMs) in superposition of orders\u2014either swap AB then BC or BC then AB\u2014based on the polariton\u2010wavelength of a single control photon. entanglement distribution between endpoints A and C.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 (for LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to marry \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d and \u201cintegrated photonic circuit\u201d in a genuinely new network primitive (no state generation):\n    1) A 4-level Bell-state analyzer on chip, using four discrete polariton\u2010wavelength bins as a qudit.\n    2) Parallel wavelength-division entanglement swapping in two channels in one static circuit.\n    3) A photonic quantum\u2013network coding \u201cbutterfly\u201d node: one static interferometer that, using a single shared link and polariton-wavelength multiplexing, carries out the two\u2010qubit teleportation network coding protocol\u2014letting two senders exchange qubits over a single physical channel without feedback.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility:\n    1) Too close to existing high-D Bell analyzers.\n    2) Already dismissed as mere parallelization.\n    3) Quantum network coding has never been implemented in integrated photonics with wavelength multiplexing; it is a true extension of entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation to multi\u2010sender multi\u2010receiver scenarios, and maps exactly onto Pytheus\u2019s resources: two pair\u2010sources, static linear\u2010optical mesh, number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities.\n  Step 3: Choose idea\u20093.\n  Step 4: Novelty: This is the first proposal for an on-chip \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum network node that uses polariton wavelength as the multiplexing DOF to implement the quantum network\u2010coding protocol (two simultaneous teleportations over one shared link). It goes beyond point\u2010to\u2010point swapping or teleportation by fusing them into a genuine network\u2010coding primitive.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can optimize exactly this kind of static linear\u2010optical network fed by probabilistic pair\u2010sources and number\u2010resolving detectors. All elements (sources, interferometer, detectors) are within its abstraction; no dynamic feedback or cavities are required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the on\u2010chip implementation of the quantum network\u2010coding \u201cbutterfly\u201d node, realized in an integrated photonic circuit that exploits polariton\u2010wavelength multiplexing. The task is not to generate a fixed state but to carry out the two\u2010qubit teleportation network code\u2014two senders S\u2081 and S\u2082 each hold an unknown qubit encoded in two polariton wavelengths (\u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082). They both inject their photons into a single shared link (a wavelength\u2010division\u2010multiplexed waveguide) plus two local Bell\u2010pair sources. A static integrated circuit then performs the joint Bell\u2010measurements in the correct pattern so that the two qubits emerge at two separate receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082\u2014exactly as in the classical \u201cbutterfly\u201d network code, but now fully quantum.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Pair source A\u2013M \u2192 modes [0,1]\n   \u2022 Pair source B\u2013M \u2192 modes [2,3]\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit S\u2081 \u2192 mode [4] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit S\u2082 \u2192 mode [5] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n\n                   \u2193\n integrated static linear\u2010optical mesh (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors:\n \u201cXOR\u201d step)\n\nProcedure & targets:\n \u2022 S\u2081\u2019s qubit in mode 4 and one photon of source A\u2013M in mode 1 undergo a Bell\u2010measurement (BM\u2081) if the control of the internal coupler is set to route \u03bb\u2081 pulses.  \n \u2022 S\u2082\u2019s qubit in mode 5 and one photon of source B\u2013M in mode 3 undergo BM\u2082 if the routing is \u03bb\u2082.  \n \u2022 Both BMs share the same physical beamsplitter but are separated in the wavelength domain.  \n \u2022 The detectors D4/D5 record which combination of BSM outcomes occurred\u2014effectively computing the required \u201cXOR\u201d (network code) and heralding two teleported qubits at R\u2081 and R\u2082.  \n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cButterfly quantum network\u2010coding node via wavelength multiplexing.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n \u2022 num_anc: 0 additional ancilla (uses only the two Bell\u2010pair sources)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 input_modes: [4,5] (the two sender qubits)  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 target_operation: simultaneous teleportation of S\u2081\u2192R\u2081 and S\u2082\u2192R\u2082 using one shared interconnect, with herald clicks at D0\u2026D5 encoding the network code.  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s impactful and generalizable:\n 1) First on\u2010chip demonstration of quantum network coding in a genuine \u201cbutterfly\u201d configuration, harnessing polariton\u2010wavelength for multiplexing instead of bulk time\u2010bins or complex switching.  \n 2) Merges entanglement swapping, teleportation, and network coding into a single static circuit\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities\u2014perfectly fitting Pytheus\u2019s toolbox.  \n 3) Lays the foundation for scalable photonic quantum routers and repeaters that compress multiple communication channels into a single waveguide.  \n 4) Directly generalizable to larger network\u2010coding topologies (e.g. multi\u2010sender multicast codes) by adding wavelengths and pair sources in an integrated mesh.\n\nWe believe this target\u2014quantum network coding in a butterfly node via polariton\u2010wavelength multiplexing\u2014will inspire a family of new on\u2010chip quantum network experiments and can be realized by Pytheus\u2019s abstract optimization of linear optics, sources, and detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010graph joint measurement already implements dual-channel entanglement swapping in one shot. INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: I brainstormed three new ways to tie together \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d and \u201cintegrated photonic circuit\u201d in a Pytheus-compatible quantum-network primitive (no state generation):\n 1) On\u2010chip entanglement purification node: take two noisy Bell pairs at two discrete polariton wavelengths (\u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082), perform a linear-optical purification measurement on one photon from each pair, and herald a higher-fidelity Bell pair on the remaining two photons.  \n 2) A frequency-bin controlled-phase router that, depending on the polariton wavelength of a control photon, applies one of two passive phase operations to an incoming qubit link.  \n 3) A two-channel \u201cquantum fanout\u201d repeater: split one incoming wavelength-encoded qubit into two outputs via ancilla-assisted linear optics to broadcast entanglement to two receivers.\n\nStep 2: I ruled out (2) as too close to standard controlled gates, and (3) as a trivial extension of repeater splitting.  \nStep 3: I selected (1), the entanglement purification node, because Pytheus has never tackled purification\u2014only swapping and teleportation.  \nStep 4: This is novel because it implements the foundational network primitive of entanglement purification in the frequency domain on chip, exploiting wavelength demultiplexing and single-rail interference to raise fidelity without feedback.  \nStep 5: It is fully feasible in Pytheus: you need two probabilistic pair sources (input Bell pairs at \u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082), a static linear interferometer with wavelength-selective couplers (the integrated circuit), and number-resolving detectors to herald successful purification. No cavities or active control are required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of an integrated-photonic entanglement-purification node exploiting polariton-wavelength multiplexing. Rather than generate a new state, the chip implements the standard two-pair purification protocol in the frequency domain: two imperfect Bell pairs\u2014one at \u03bb\u2081 (modes 0 & 1) and one at \u03bb\u2082 (modes 2 & 3)\u2014enter a passive static interferometer that demultiplexes the wavelengths, interferes one photon of each pair on a beam\u2010splitter mesh, and routes the others to two distant outputs (modes 4 & 5). Coincident detections on two ancilla detectors herald a high-fidelity Bell pair between the remaining photons.\n\nVisualization (modes numbered top\u2192bottom, detectors left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell pair source P\u2081 at \u03bb\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]\n   \u2022 Bell pair source P\u2082 at \u03bb\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]\n               \u2193\n integrated wavelength-demultiplexing + static beam-splitter network\n               \u2193\n detectors:\n   \u2022 D0, D1 (interference outputs for purification herald)\n   \u2022 D2, D3 (output channels for purified pair to remote nodes)\n\nKey Pytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cOn-chip entanglement purification via polariton-wavelength multiplexing.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n \u2022 num_anc: 0 extra single emitters (ancilla detection uses the two input photons)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_operation: conditional post-selection\u2014when detectors D0&D1 click in coincidence, modes 2&3 collapse into a purified Bell state.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:\n1) It is the first passive integrated demonstration of entanglement purification in the frequency domain, a crucial primitive for realistic quantum networks subject to loss and noise.  \n2) It leverages discrete polariton wavelengths to multiplex purification operations, saving footprint and eliminating active switching.  \n3) Once found, the same design can be extended to multiple purification stages or d-level purification by adding more wavelength channels and interferometric stages.  \n4) All elements\u2014probabilistic pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014are directly supported by Pytheus\u2019s abstract optimization framework."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer on a Hybrid-Waveguide Optical Phased Array\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip 5\u00d75 hybrid-waveguide interferometer that, by feeding in three unknown photonic qubits and two ancilla photons and programming five integrated phase shifters, realizes on-demand projections onto any of the eight three-qubit GHZ basis states. Each GHZ basis element produces a distinct five-photon number-resolved click pattern, enabling unambiguous GHZ-state measurement purely via static linear optics and post-selected detection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum-Controlled Time-Bin Basis Entanglement Swapping in the Telecom Band\n\nAbstract: We realize a basis-controlled entanglement swapping protocol for telecom-band time-bin qubits by preparing a single-photon control qubit in the superposition (|early\u232a+e^{i\u03c6}|late\u232a) to route two SPDC-generated Bell pairs between nodes A\u2013R and R\u2013C into either a Z-basis (M_Z) or an X-basis (M_X) Bell-swap module. Heralding coincidences in M_Z versus M_X project the target remote nodes A and C onto \u03a6\u207a_Z or \u03a6\u207a_X respectively, and by scanning \u03c6 and performing two-qubit tomography we observe high-visibility fringes certifying a coherent superposition of distinct Bell-state swap bases beyond ordinary swapping or switching.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear-Optical Quantum Perceptron Activation Gate\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a measurement-induced non-linear \u201cquantum perceptron\u201d gate in a fully passive linear-optical network by combining two unknown photonic qubit inputs with Bell-pair ancillas and post-selection heralding. The target is a single output qubit at node 2 whose probability of measuring |1\u27e9 realizes a tunable threshold (or sigmoid) function f(w\u2081\u00b7x\u2081 + w\u2082\u00b7x\u2082), providing a genuine non-unitary activation primitive for photonic quantum machine learning.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).  Conditioned on one of the six generalized Bell outcomes, this linear-optics and number-resolving detection scheme heralds the target qubit\u2013qutrit Bell state \u201600\u27e9+ei\u03c6\u201612\u27e9/\u221a2 across the two distinct Hilbert spaces without feedback, hyper-entanglement, or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Square-Network Bell Test via Wavefront\u2010Shaped Nanophotonic Resonator Analyzers\n\nAbstract: We propose a fully static four\u2010node cycle experiment (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D\u2013A) that employs four independent entangled photon\u2010pair sources and two 4\u00d74 multiport Bell\u2013state analyzers implemented by wavefront shaping of nanophotonic resonator arrays at nodes B and D, while nodes A and C perform local single\u2010photon measurements. By correlating the joint Bell outcomes at B and D with the local measurement results at A and C, this configuration realizes the target \u201cBell_test_stat\u201d square\u2010network Bell inequality, constituting the first photonic demonstration of nonlocal correlations around a cycle without feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Mid\u2010Gap Bell\u2010Pair Extraction in a Dimerized Photonic SSH Repeater Chain  \n\nMini\u2010abstract:  \nWe implement a linear\u2010optical SSH chain of 2M+1 spatial modes using alternating strong (two\u2010pair) and weak (single\u2010pair) photon sources, performing heralded Bell\u2010state measurements at each non\u2010central node. Post-selecting a fixed Bell outcome in each Bell-state measurement and employing only passive 50:50 beam splitters, fixed delay cavities, ancilla detectors, and single-photon emitters realizes a genuine quantum routing primitive that maps |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 \u2192 (|\u03c8\u27e9\u1d66 + |\u03c8\u27e9\ud835\udcb8)/\u221a2 without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose as a target the design of a complete 4-dimensional Bell\u2010basis analyzer for two photonic qudits encoded in four discrete \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d modes, implemented in an integrated linear photonic circuit. Rather than generating a state, the goal is a measurement network that, upon detection clicks, unambiguously projects any incoming pair of 4-mode qudits onto which one of the 16 maximally entangled Bell states they occupied.  \n\nVisualization of the general structure (modes 0\u20133 are qudit A, 4\u20137 are qudit B; modes 8\u201311 are ancilla single-photon sources):  \n emitters: [8] [9] [10] [11]  \n        \u2193  \n integrated linear network (to be optimized)  \n        \u2193  \n detectors: 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 anc. det. 9 anc. det. 10 anc. det. 11 anc. det.  \n\nKey configuration elements for pytheus:\n\u2022 description: \u201c4d Bell\u2010state analyzer for wavelength\u2010encoded qudits.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 4 (single_emitters at nodes 8\u201311)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [8,9,10,11]  \n\u2022 target_quantum: the 16 four-mode \u201cBell\u201d patterns (e.g. strings \u201800, 11, 22, \u2026 33\u2019 but generalized to all 16 combinations)  \n\u2022 number_resolving: True  \n\u2022 removed_connections: [] (no forbidden links; all couplings allowed)  \n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n\u2022 Demonstrates the first on-chip complete Bell measurement in dimension d>2, using \u201cwavelength\u201d modes as an abstract stand-in for polariton wavelengths.  \n\u2022 Once found, the same circuit architecture can be generalized to d=5,6,\u2026 or to multiplexed repeater nodes.  \n\u2022 Enables high-dimensional entanglement swapping and teleportation protocols in integrated photonics, probing fundamental limits of linear-optical Bell measurements.  \n\u2022 Opens a path toward wavelength-multiplexed quantum routers and repeaters without relying on cavities or dynamic feedback.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While a 4-dimensional Bell-state analyzer is an important target, this proposal closely mirrors the ensemble\u2019s \u201cPassive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts.\u201d Both seek a static linear-optical circuit with ancilla photons and number-resolving detectors to unambiguously discriminate all 16 ququart Bell states. Because the core novelty (a complete d=4 Bell analyzer in integrated photonics) has already been captured, this idea is not sufficiently distinct or groundbreaking for a PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The concept duplicates the ensemble\u2019s passive 4D Bell-state analyzer for ququarts. To be novel, you must introduce fundamentally new ingredients\u2014e.g. non-linear interactions, topological or adaptive elements, or a measurement primitive beyond straightforward linear-optical generalization to higher d.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose as a target the design of a wavelength-division-multiplexed entanglement-swapping station on an integrated photonic circuit. proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This two-channel wavelength-multiplexed swap is essentially It offers no genuinely new measurement primitive or nontrivial network effect\u2014just parallel copies of a standard entanglement swap.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal merely ported time-bin multiplexing to wavelength channels without adding a fundamentally new ingredient.
