Using a small number of ancilla photons and a static linear\u2010optical waveguide network, unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states in the frequency\u2010bin basis:\n  \u03a8\u00b1 = (|\u03bb\u2081_A,\u03bb\u2082_B> \u00b1 |\u03bb\u2082_A,\u03bb\u2081_B>)/\u221a2  \n  \u03a6\u00b1 = (|\u03bb\u2081_A,\u03bb\u2081_B> \u00b1 |\u03bb\u2082_A,\u03bb\u2082_B>)/\u221a2  \n\nGeneral structure (modes labeled 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Pair source (\u03bb\u2081\u2013\u03bb\u2082 entangled) \u2192 modes 2,3  \n   \u2022 Single-photon sources (ancilla at \u03bb\u2081) \u2192 mode 4  \n   \u2022 Single-photon sources (ancilla at \u03bb\u2082) \u2192 mode 5  \n\n             \u2193\n   static integrated linear circuit (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5   D6  D7\n\nMapping:\n \u2022 Inputs: modes 0&1 carry the unknown frequency\u2010bin qubits for A and B.  \n \u2022 Ancilla: one entangled pair in modes 2&3 spans \u03bb\u2081\u2013\u03bb\u2082; The goal is to reproduce the nonclassical correlation pattern characteristic of the triangle network (violating any classical \u201cbilocal\u201d hidden\u2010variable bound) purely via passive optics and heralding\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no state generation.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n  emitters:\n    \u2022 Pair source Instead of generating a fixed entangled state, the chip should perform one of two entanglement-swapping operations\u2014between remote nodes A&C or between B&D\u2014based solely on the polariton-wavelength of a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and if that photon is prepared in a superposition of the two wavelengths, the router will implement a coherent superposition of the two route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the coherent sum of those two orderings, yielding a superposed entanglement link.  \n \u2022 The chip\u2019s success is heralded by distinct 3-click patterns: one signature for \u201cA\u2013C swapped,\u201d another for \u201cB\u2013D swapped,\u201d each correlated with which control-ancilla detector clicked.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled entanglement from AB to AC.  \n \u2022 Control in \u03bb\u2082 routes so that BSM\u2082 (between modes 0&3) occurs first, swapping to BC.  \n \u2022 Control in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2 yields a coherent superposition of these two swap orders, verified by distinct multi-click heralding patterns.  \n\nPytheus config hints:\n \u2022 polariton\u2010wavelength as a control knob in integrated photonic routers.  \n3) Blueprint for scaling: add more swap stations and wavelengths to create superposition of arbitrary network orders. The task is not to generate a fixed state but to carry out the two\u2010qubit teleportation network code\u2014two senders S\u2081 and S\u2082 each hold an unknown qubit encoded in two polariton wavelengths (\u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082). A static integrated circuit then performs the joint Bell\u2010measurements in the correct pattern so that the two qubits emerge at two separate receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082\u2014exactly as in the classical \u201cbutterfly\u201d network code, but now fully quantum.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Pair source \u201cXOR\u201d step)\n\nProcedure & targets:\n \u2022 S\u2081\u2019s qubit in mode 4 and one photon of source A\u2013M in mode 1 undergo a Bell\u2010measurement (BM\u2081) if the control of the internal coupler is set to route \u03bb\u2081 pulses.  \n \u2022 S\u2082\u2019s qubit in mode 5 and one photon of source B\u2013M in mode 3 undergo BM\u2082 if the routing is \u03bb\u2082.  \n \u2022 the required \u201cXOR\u201d (network code) and heralding two teleported qubits at R\u2081 and R\u2082.  \n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cButterfly quantum single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 input_modes: [4,5] (the two sender qubits)  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 target_operation: simultaneous teleportation of S\u2081\u2192R\u2081 and complex switching.  \n 2) Merges entanglement swapping, teleportation, and network coding into a single static circuit\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities\u2014perfectly fitting Pytheus\u2019s toolbox.  \n 3) Lays the foundation for scalable photonic quantum routers and repeaters that compress multiple communication channels into a single waveguide.  \n 4) Directly generalizable to larger primitive already in the ensemble (\u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\u201d) recast with a different encoding. Rather than generate a new state, the chip implements the standard two-pair purification protocol in the frequency domain: two imperfect Bell pairs\u2014one at \u03bb\u2081 (modes 0 & 1) and one at \u03bb\u2082 (modes 2 & 3)\u2014enter a passive static interferometer that demultiplexes the wavelengths, interferes one photon of each pair on a beam\u2010splitter mesh, and routes the others to two distant outputs (modes 4 & 5). Coincident detections on two ancilla detectors herald a high-fidelity Bell pair between the remaining photons.\n\nVisualization (modes numbered top\u2192bottom, detectors left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell pair source P\u2081 at \u03bb\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]\n   \u2022 Bell pair source P\u2082 at \u03bb\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]\n               \u2193\n integrated wavelength-demultiplexing + static beam-splitter network\n               \u2193\n detectors:\n   \u2022 D0, D1 (interference outputs for purification herald)\n   \u2022 D2, D3 (output channels for purified pair to remote nodes)\n\nKey Pytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cOn-chip entanglement purification via polariton-wavelength multiplexing.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n \u2022 num_anc: 0 extra single emitters (ancilla detection uses the two input photons)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_operation: conditional post-selection\u2014when detectors D0&D1 click in coincidence, modes 2&3 collapse into a purified Bell state.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:\n1) It is the first passive integrated demonstration of entanglement purification in the frequency domain, a crucial primitive for realistic quantum networks subject to loss and noise.  \n2) It leverages discrete polariton wavelengths to multiplex purification operations, saving footprint and eliminating active switching.  \n3) Once found, the same design can be extended to multiple purification stages or d-level purification by adding more wavelength channels and interferometric stages.  \n4) All elements\u2014probabilistic pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014are directly supported by Pytheus\u2019s abstract optimization framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposal is just the standard two-pair entanglement-purification protocol recast into wavelength-division multiplexing on chip. The ensemble already contains on-chip purification primitives (e.g. \u201cMode-Division-Multiplexed On-Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\u201d and even photon-blockade\u2013assisted purification), and nothing fundamentally new is introduced beyond swapping spatial multiplexing for frequency bins.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Entanglement purification in linear optics\u2014whether via mode-division or frequency-division multiplexing\u2014has been covered. To be novel for PRL you need a genuinely new ingredient (e.g. cross-frequency interference enabling multi-pair cascaded purification without extra ancilla, topological protection of the purified subspace, or an adaptive/indefinite-order purification network beyond the standard two-pair scheme)."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. Each node receives two modes at two different wavelengths (one from each of two sources), applies a fixed linear\u2010optic transformation (to be optimized), and performs photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection. The goal is to reproduce the nonclassical correlation pattern characteristic of the triangle network (violating any classical \u201cbilocal\u201d hidden\u2010variable bound) purely via passive optics and heralding\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no state generation.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; The goal is not to generate a new state but to implement the measurement that projects any two unknown qubits (each encoded into a single photon occupying \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082) onto the symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces, thereby revealing if they are identical or not. This is a core quantum-network primitive (used in fingerprinting, entanglement verification, routing), now in the polariton-wavelength domain and on-chip.\n\nGeneral structure (modes numbered 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; modes 2&3 carry qubit B; modes 4&5 an ancilla Bell pair |00>+|11> (abstract).  \n \u2022 The linear network mixes all six modes so that a particular pattern of 4 or 6 clicks unambiguously heralds the symmetric vs. antisymmetric projection of A\u2297B.  \n \u2022 Detector patterns (e.g. double clicks in certain pairs) signal \u201cidentical\u201d (symmetric) or \u201cdifferent\u201d (antisymmetric).\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency-bin SWAP-test on integrated photonic chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1  (one probabilistic Bell pair at modes [4,5])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the two projector outcomes\u2014\u201csymmetric\u201d and \u201cantisymmetric\u201d\u2014encoded as distinct detector-click patterns across D0\u2026D5.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable and expandable:\n 1) First on-chip SWAP test in the frequency/polariton-wavelength domain.  \n 2) A primitive for multiplexed entanglement verification, quantum fingerprinting, error-diagnosis in wavelength-division networks.  \n 3) Immediately generalizable to d-dimensional \u201cSWAP tests\u201d for qudits in more wavelengths.  \n 4) Entirely within pytheus\u2019s toolkit: pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no forbidden cavities or active feed-forward.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel at the PRL level, you need to go beyond a direct port of the standard SWAP test to another encoding. route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the detector-click signatures, one for each swap outcome, plus their coherent superposition.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this is powerful and Pytheus can optimize exactly this network.\n  Step 3: Choose idea 3.\n  Step 4: Novelty: First on-chip frequency-demultiplexed teleportation router\u2014combines polariton\u2010wavelength encoding and integrated photonics to realize a heralded routing of a qubit via teleportation, with no active feed-forward.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Uses two probabilistic pair sources (ancilla for \u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082), one unknown input photon in a wavelength superposition, a static linear interferometer with wavelength-selective couplers, and number-resolving detectors. All elements map directly to Pytheus\u2019s abstract model\u2014no cavities or feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of a frequency-demultiplexed teleportation router on a single integrated photonic chip. The chip takes one unknown photonic qubit encoded in two discrete \u201cpolariton\u201d wavelengths (\u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082) and, via two Bell-pair ancilla sources and a static linear\u2010optic network, teleports it onto one of two spatial output channels: output A for \u03bb\u2081, output B for \u03bb\u2082. If the input is in a superposition of \u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082, the router yields a coherent superposition of path A and path B. No dynamic switching or feedback is required\u2014only heralded post-selection.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit \u2192 mode 0 (encodes \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2081 \u2192 modes [1,2]  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2082 \u2192 modes [3,4]  \n             \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optics circuit  \n  (wavelength\u2010demultiplexer + two Bell\u2010measurement modules  \n   sharing the same beam-splitter mesh)  \n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2081 module  \n   D2 D3   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2082 module  \n   D4      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path A  \n   D5      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path B\n\nOperation:\n \u2022 The input photon at \u03bb\u2081 is routed by the demux into BSM\u2081 (mixing with ancilla modes 1&2). A coincidence at D0&D1 heralds teleportation onto ancilla mode 2, which we route to D4 (output A).  \n \u2022 Similarly, an input at \u03bb\u2082 is demuxed into BSM\u2082 (mixing modes 3&4), and D2&D3 click herald teleportation onto mode 4, routed to D5 (output B).  \n \u2022 If input = \u03b1|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+\u03b2|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9, the static network preserves coherence, producing \u03b1 at D4 and \u03b2 at D5, a frequency-to-path conversion by teleportation.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency-demultiplexed teleportation router on integrated chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[1,2],[3,4]]  (ancilla for \u03bb\u2081 & \u03bb\u2082)  \n \u2022 num_anc: 0 single_emitters (all ancilla from pair_sources)  \n \u2022 input_modes: [0]  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the two heralded projector outcomes\u2014\u201cteleported to A\u201d vs. \u201cteleported to B\u201d\u2014encoded as distinct click pairs {D0,D1,D4} or {D2,D3,D5}.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4]] to forbid \u03bb\u2081 input into the \u03bb\u2082 BSM and vice versa, enforcing clean demultiplexing.\n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable:\n 1) Introduces the first passive, heralded teleportation-based quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength encoding to choose the teleportation channel.  \n 2) Converts frequency-encoded qubits into path-encoded ones via teleportation, a new network transformation primitive.  \n 3) Directly generalizes to N-wavelength demultiplexing or multi-output routing by adding more ancilla pair sources.  \n 4) Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: probabilistic pair sources, static linear optics (including wavelength demux simulated by removed_connections), and number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities or active feed-forward needed."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement-Assisted Teleported Error-Detecting Channel (EAQECC-Teleport)\n\nAbstract: We implement a linear-optical network that realizes the target transformation\u2014teleporting a logical qubit from sender A to receiver D while detecting any single-photon erasure\u2014by embedding a (3,1) entanglement-assisted quantum error-detecting code across two relay nodes B and C. Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources and post-selected Bell measurements perform preshared entanglement encoding at A, entanglement swapping at B/C, and decoding at D, heralding both correct qubit transmission and detection of single-photon loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Three\u2010Photon Repetition\u2010Code Logical\u2010Bell State Analyzer in Silicon Photonics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose and design an integrated silicon\u2010photonic circuit that implements an error\u2010detecting logical\u2010Bell state measurement on two qubits encoded in the three\u2010photon repetition code, using six waveguide modes, tunable Mach\u2013Zehnder interferometer parity\u2010check modules, and a final multiport interferometer. This analyzer unambiguously discriminates all four logical Bell states (|\u03a6\u00b1\u27e9\u2097, |\u03a8\u00b1\u27e9\u2097) while simultaneously heralding single\u2010photon loss errors via on\u2010chip photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, fully compatible with Pyth\u00e9us linear\u2010optics primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Dissipative Cyclic Entanglement Shifter for Photonic Bell Pairs\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a static, single-step dissipative network primitive that cyclically reconfigures three pre-existing photonic Bell pairs (modes AB, CD, EF) into the target six-photon cyclic permutation subspace, yielding new entangled pairs AD, CF, and EB via a two-ancilla-photon heralding event. By mixing only the \u201cmiddle\u201d modes with two ancilla photons through beam splitters and phase shifters\u2014and detecting exactly one photon on each ancilla detector\u2014this passive linear-optical protocol achieves the desired entanglement shift without active feedback or cavities and plugs directly into the Pytheus toolkit.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. encoded as four disjoint sets of 4-click patterns across D0\u2026D7.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable:\n 1) Demonstrates the first To be novel, introduce a fundamentally new ingredient (e.g. non-linear mixing, topological or indefinite-order routing, or a multi-frequency joint\u2010interference measurement beyond straightforward ancilla boosting).\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose as a Pytheus target the design of a wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router in an integrated photonic circuit. Instead of generating a fixed entangled state, the chip should perform one of two entanglement-swapping operations\u2014between remote nodes A&C or between B&D\u2014based solely on the polariton-wavelength of a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and if that photon is prepared in a superposition of the two wavelengths, the router will implement a coherent superposition of the two swap outcomes (a first step toward indefinite-order entanglement distribution). \n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 in |\u03bb\u2081\u27e9 or |\u03bb\u2082\u27e9 or their superposition)\n\n                   \u2193\n  integrated linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   D2 D3   D4 D5\n   (A  C)  (B  D)  (ctrl anc)\n\nOperation & targets:\n \u2022 If the control photon is in wavelength \u03bb\u2081, the linear network should route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the coherent sum of those two orderings, yielding a superposed entanglement link.  \n \u2022 The chip\u2019s success is heralded by distinct 3-click patterns: one signature for \u201cA\u2013C swapped,\u201d another for \u201cB\u2013D swapped,\u201d each correlated with which control-ancilla detector clicked.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled Rather than generate a new state, the chip implements the standard two-pair purification protocol in the frequency domain: two imperfect Bell pairs\u2014one at \u03bb\u2081 (modes 0 & 1) and one at \u03bb\u2082 (modes 2 & 3)\u2014enter a passive static interferometer that demultiplexes the wavelengths, interferes one photon of each pair on a beam\u2010splitter mesh, and routes the others to two distant outputs (modes 4 & 5). noise.  \n2) It leverages discrete polariton wavelengths to multiplex purification operations, saving footprint and eliminating active switching.  \n3) Once found, the same design can be extended to The chip takes one unknown photonic qubit encoded in two discrete \u201cpolariton\u201d wavelengths (\u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082) and, via two Bell-pair ancilla sources and a static linear\u2010optic network, teleports it onto one of two spatial output channels: output A for \u03bb\u2081, output B for \u03bb\u2082. If the input is in a superposition of \u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082, the router yields a coherent superposition of path A and path B. No dynamic switching or feedback is required\u2014only heralded post-selection.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit \u2192 mode 0 (encodes \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2081 \u2192 modes [1,2]  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2082 \u2192 modes [3,4]  \n             \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optics circuit  \n  (wavelength\u2010demultiplexer + two Bell\u2010measurement modules  \n   sharing the same beam-splitter mesh)  \n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2081 module  \n   D2 D3   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2082 module  \n   D4      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path A  \n   D5      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path B\n\nOperation:\n \u2022 The input photon at \u03bb\u2081 is routed by the demux into BSM\u2081 (mixing with ancilla modes 1&2). A coincidence at D0&D1 heralds teleportation onto ancilla mode 2, which we route to D4 (output A).  \n \u2022 Similarly, an input at \u03bb\u2082 is demuxed into BSM\u2082 (mixing modes 3&4), and D2&D3 click herald teleportation onto mode 4, routed to D5 (output B).  \n \u2022 If input = \u03b1|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+\u03b2|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9, the static network preserves coherence, producing \u03b1 at D4 and \u03b2 at D5, a frequency-to-path conversion by teleportation.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency-demultiplexed teleportation router on integrated chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[1,2],[3,4]]  (ancilla for \u03bb\u2081 & \u03bb\u2082)  \n \u2022 num_anc: 0 single_emitters (all ancilla from pair_sources)  \n \u2022 input_modes: [0]  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the two heralded projector outcomes\u2014\u201cteleported to A\u201d vs. \u201cteleported to B\u201d\u2014encoded as distinct click pairs {D0,D1,D4} or {D2,D3,D5}.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4]] to forbid \u03bb\u2081 input into the \u03bb\u2082 BSM and vice versa, enforcing clean demultiplexing.\n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable:\n 1) Introduces the first passive, heralded teleportation-based quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength encoding to choose the teleportation channel.  \n 2) Converts frequency-encoded qubits into path-encoded ones via teleportation, a new network transformation primitive.  \n 3) Directly generalizes to N-wavelength demultiplexing or multi-output routing by adding more ancilla pair sources.  \n 4) Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: probabilistic pair sources, static linear optics (including wavelength demux simulated by removed_connections), and number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities or active feed-forward needed.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The frequency\u2010demultiplexed teleportation router is essentially the same dual\u2010destination teleportation switch already in the ensemble, only recast into polariton\u2010wavelength encoding, without introducing any new measurement primitive or nontrivial network effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip.\u201d To be novel at the PRL level, you need to add genuinely new ingredients\u2014e.g. cross\u2010frequency interference effects, topological or indefinite\u2010order routing, nonlinear measurement primitives, or an adaptive network element beyond straightforward teleportation routing."

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"polariton wavelength\" and \"integrated photonic circuit\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Instead of the usual single-ancilla limitation, our network uses two probabilistic Bell-pair sources\u2014one at wavelength \u03bb\u2081, one at \u03bb\u2082\u2014as ancilla resources. \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d and \u201cintegrated photonic circuit\u201d into a new quantum-network primitive (no state-generation):\n   1) A 4-dimensional Bell-analyzer on chip using four polariton wavelengths.  \n   2) A two-channel wavelength-division multiplexed entanglement swap in one static circuit.  \n   3) A wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router: a static integrated circuit that, depending on the polariton-wavelength of a control photon, performs one of two entanglement-swapping operations between remote nodes A\u2013C or B\u2013D, and in superposition it yields a coherent superposition of which link was entangled.\n Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:\n   1) Too close to existing high-D Bell analyzers.  \n   2) Already flagged as parallelization of standard swaps.  \n   3) The controlled-router is genuinely new: it elevates entanglement swapping to a programmable, wavelength-encoded \u201cquantum router\u201d primitive, opening indefinite-order and multiplexed routing, and maps cleanly to Pytheus\u2019s resources (two pair sources, one single photon emitter as control, a static interferometer, number-resolving detectors).\n Step 3: I choose idea 3.\n Step 4: This is novel because no one has proposed a passive, wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router on an integrated chip that can coherently choose (or superpose) which pair of remote nodes to entangle.  \n Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only needs:\n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources (modes 0\u20131 and 2\u20133).  \n   \u2022 One single-photon emitter as a wavelength-encoded control qubit (mode 4).  \n   \u2022 A static linear-optical circuit (to be optimized).  \n   \u2022 Number-resolving detectors at the four node outputs plus two ancilla detectors.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of a wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router in an integrated photonic circuit. Instead of generating a fixed entangled state, the chip should perform one of two entanglement-swapping operations\u2014between remote nodes A&C or between B&D\u2014based solely on the polariton-wavelength of a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and if that photon is prepared in a superposition of the two wavelengths, the router will implement a coherent superposition of the two swap outcomes (a first step toward indefinite-order entanglement distribution). \n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]  (targets A & C)  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]  (targets B & D)  \n   \u2022 Single-photon control E \u2192 mode [4]  (prepared in |\u03bb\u2081\u27e9 or |\u03bb\u2082\u27e9 or their superposition)\n\n                   \u2193\n  integrated linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   D2 D3   D4 D5\n   (A  C)  (B  D)  (ctrl anc)\n\nOperation & targets:\n \u2022 If the control photon is in wavelength \u03bb\u2081, the linear network should route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the coherent sum of those two orderings, yielding a superposed entanglement link.  \n \u2022 The chip\u2019s success is heralded by distinct 3-click patterns: one signature for \u201cA\u2013C swapped,\u201d another for \u201cB\u2013D swapped,\u201d each correlated with which control-ancilla detector clicked.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled entanglement-swap router on chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (control emitter at mode 4)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4]  \n \u2022 pair sources: [[0,1], [2,3]]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two sets of detector-click signatures, one for each swap outcome, plus their coherent superposition.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this is powerful and extensible:\n 1) Introduces the first on-chip, passive quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength as a control qubit to choose and even superpose which remote link is entangled.  \n 2) Lays groundwork for indefinite-order entanglement distribution and multi-channel routing by simply adding more wavelengths and sources.  \n 3) Fully matches Pytheus\u2019s abstract model\u2014probabilistic pair sources, a single-photon emitter, a static interferometer, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014without requiring feedback or cavities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates similar ensembles exist.  \nStep 3: Select idea 1.\nStep 4: Novelty\u2014this is the first passive, on-chip proposal for indefinite-order entanglement swapping controlled by a superposition of polariton wavelengths, turning entanglement-swapping into a higher-order quantum network primitive.  \nStep 5: Feasibility\u2014Pytheus can optimize probabilistic Bell-pair sources (for channels AB and BC), a single-photon emitter (control in \u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082), a static linear interferometer with wavelength-selective couplers, and number-resolving detectors. Instead of a fixed swap, the network performs two Bell\u2010measurements (BSMs) in superposition of orders\u2014either swap AB then BC or BC then AB\u2014based on the polariton\u2010wavelength of a single control photon. entanglement distribution between endpoints A and C.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 (for classical \u201cbutterfly\u201d network code, but now fully quantum.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Pair source \u2192 mode [5] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n\n                   \u2193\n integrated static linear\u2010optical mesh (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors:\n \u201cXOR\u201d step)\n\nProcedure & targets:\n \u2022 S\u2081\u2019s qubit in mode 4 and one photon of source A\u2013M in mode 1 undergo a Bell\u2010measurement (BM\u2081) if the control of the internal coupler is set to route \u03bb\u2081 pulses.  \n \u2022 S\u2082\u2019s qubit in mode 5 and one photon of source B\u2013M in mode 3 undergo BM\u2082 if the routing is \u03bb\u2082.  \n \u2022 complex switching.  \n 2) Merges entanglement swapping, teleportation, and network coding into a single static circuit\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities\u2014perfectly fitting Pytheus\u2019s toolbox.  \n 3) Lays the foundation for scalable photonic quantum routers and repeaters that compress multiple communication channels into a single waveguide.  \n 4) Directly generalizable to larger The chip takes one unknown photonic qubit encoded in two discrete \u201cpolariton\u201d wavelengths (\u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082) and, via two Bell-pair ancilla sources and a static linear\u2010optic network, teleports it onto one of two spatial output channels: output A for \u03bb\u2081, output B for \u03bb\u2082. If the input is in a superposition of \u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082, the router yields a coherent superposition of path A and path B. No dynamic switching or feedback is required\u2014only heralded post-selection.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit \u2192 mode 0 (encodes \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2081 \u2192 modes [1,2]  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2082 \u2192 modes [3,4]  \n             \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optics circuit  \n  (wavelength\u2010demultiplexer + two Bell\u2010measurement modules  \n   sharing the same beam-splitter mesh)  \n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2081 module  \n   D2 D3   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2082 module  \n   D4      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path A  \n   D5      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path B\n\nOperation:\n \u2022 The input photon at \u03bb\u2081 is routed by the demux into BSM\u2081 (mixing with ancilla modes 1&2). A coincidence at D0&D1 heralds teleportation onto ancilla mode 2, which we route to D4 (output A).  \n \u2022 Similarly, an input at \u03bb\u2082 is demuxed into BSM\u2082 (mixing modes 3&4), and D2&D3 click herald teleportation onto mode 4, routed to D5 (output B).  \n \u2022 If input = \u03b1|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+\u03b2|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9, the static network preserves coherence, producing \u03b1 at D4 and \u03b2 at D5, a frequency-to-path conversion by teleportation.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency-demultiplexed teleportation router on integrated chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[1,2],[3,4]]  (ancilla for \u03bb\u2081 & \u03bb\u2082)  \n \u2022 num_anc: 0 single_emitters (all ancilla from pair_sources)  \n \u2022 input_modes: [0]  \n {D0,D1,D4} or {D2,D3,D5}.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4]] to forbid \u03bb\u2081 input into the \u03bb\u2082 BSM and vice versa, enforcing clean demultiplexing.\n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable:\n 1) Introduces the first passive, heralded teleportation-based quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength encoding to choose the teleportation channel.  \n 2) Converts frequency-encoded qubits into path-encoded ones via teleportation, a new network transformation primitive.  \n 3) Directly generalizes to N-wavelength demultiplexing or multi-output routing by adding more ancilla pair sources.  \n 4) Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: probabilistic pair sources, static linear optics (including wavelength demux simulated by removed_connections), and number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities or active feed-forward needed.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation     "output": "We propose as a Pytheus target the first **indefinite-order quantum-network coding node** realized on a single static integrated photonic circuit, using **polariton-wavelength** as the control qubit.  Instead of two Bell-measurements happening in a fixed sequence, the circuit performs the two required Bell-state measurements (BSM\u2081 and BSM\u2082) in a coherent **superposition of orders**, thereby merging the ideas of the quantum SWITCH and the quantum-butterfly network code.\n\n\u2014 Context: in the standard butterfly network\u2010coding protocol two distant senders S\u2081 and S\u2082 each hold an unknown qubit; they share one Bell pair with the central node M, and M shares another Bell pair with each respective receiver R\u2081, R\u2082.  Node M must perform two BSMs (first on S\u2081\u2013M, then on S\u2082\u2013M) and combine their classical outcomes.  Here we elevate that to a true higher-order quantum network primitive by allowing the **order** of those two BSMs to be controlled (and even superposed) by a **single control photon** encoded in two discrete polariton wavelengths \u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082\u2014**all in one static chip**.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20137 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D7 left\u2192right):\n\n  emitters:\n    \u2022 Bell-pair source P\u2081 (for M\u2013R\u2081) \u2192 modes [0,1]  \n    \u2022 Bell-pair source P\u2082 (for M\u2013R\u2082) \u2192 modes [2,3]  \n    \u2022 Unknown sender qubit S\u2081         \u2192 mode [4] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n    \u2022 Unknown sender qubit S\u2082         \u2192 mode [5] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n    \u2022 Control photon E                \u2192 mode [6] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)\n\n                 \u2193  \n  static integrated linear-optical interferometer  \n  (wavelength-demultiplexer + mesh of beam splitters, optimized by Pytheus)  \n                 \u2193  \n  detectors (number resolving):\n    D0 D1   \u2190 BSM outputs when first-measurement  \n    D2 D3   \u2190 BSM outputs when second-measurement  \n    D4 D5   \u2190 control-photon ancilla clicks  \n    D6 D7   \u2190 heralds for outputs to R\u2081, R\u2082\n\nOperation & targets:\n\n  \u2022 If the control photon is in \u03bb\u2081 \u2192 the circuit passively routes so that M performs BSM\u2081 (on S\u2081 & P\u2081) first, then BSM\u2082 (on S\u2082 & P\u2082).  \n  \u2022 If control is in \u03bb\u2082 \u2192 the routing inverts: BSM\u2082 happens before BSM\u2081.  \n  \u2022 If control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9 + |\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2 \u2192 M implements the two BSMs in a **coherent superposition of orders**, a genuine indefinite-order network code.  \n  \u2022 Distinct multi-click patterns {D0,D1,D4,D6} vs. {D2,D3,D5,D7} herald which receiver gets which teleported qubit\u2014and superpositions thereof.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n\n  description: \u201cIndefinite-order quantum network code via polariton-wavelength control.\u201d  \n  pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n  num_anc: 1  (single emitter at [6] for the control photon)  \n  single_emitters: [6]  \n  input_modes: [4,5]  (the two sender qubits)  \n  target_operation: two BSMs whose **order** is coherently controlled by the wavelength of mode 6; heralding click\u2010patterns for the four possible outcomes.  \n  number_resolving: True  \n  removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this is novel and exciting:\n\n 1) It fuses **quantum SWITCH** (indefinite causal order) with **quantum network coding** (butterfly protocol)\u2014two active research frontiers\u2014into one **passive** integrated chip.  \n 2) Uses **polariton-wavelength** as a static, no-feedback control knob to select and superpose the sequence of network operations.  \n 3) Demonstrates a genuinely higher-order network primitive beyond fixed-order swapping or teleportation: the **order** of the two measurements becomes itself a quantum degree of freedom.  \n 4) Opens the door to **higher-order network codes** (superposed routing topologies) and scales by adding more wavelengths and pair sources.  \n 5) Fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstraction: only probabilistic pair\u2010sources, one single\u2010photon emitter, a static linear interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no resonances, no active feed-forward. \n\nThis scheme should motivate a new class of integrated photonic network experiments combining modern quantum-optical network theory with wavelength multiplexing and passive linear optics\u2014and yield a striking theory paper on indefinite-order quantum network coding."
}

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"polariton wavelength\" and \"integrated photonic circuit\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Each node receives two modes at two different wavelengths (one from each of two sources), applies a fixed linear\u2010optic transformation (to be optimized), and performs photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection. The goal is to reproduce the nonclassical correlation pattern characteristic of the triangle network (violating any classical \u201cbilocal\u201d hidden\u2010variable bound) purely via passive optics and heralding\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no state generation.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; are injected, projects the joint inputs onto the symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces\u2014i.e. it implements the SWAP-test measurement, a fundamental quantum-network primitive for fingerprinting and entanglement verification.\n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit A \u2192 modes [0,1] linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by pytheus)\n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0  D1   D2  D3   D4  D5\n\nMapping & operation:\n \u2022 Inputs in modes 0/1 and 2/3 carry the two unknown frequency-bin qubits.  \n \u2022 The ancilla Bell pair in 4/5 supplies the entanglement resource.  \n \u2022 The optimized network mixes all six modes so that symmetric inputs (qubits equal) yield one unique detector-click signature, while antisymmetric inputs (qubits different) yield a different signature.  \n \u2022 By postselecting on these distinct click patterns, one can unambiguously decide \u201cidentical\u201d vs. \u201cdifferent\u201d for the two qubits.\n\nSuggested pytheus config hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cIntegrated-photonic SWAP-test for frequency-bin qubits.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (one Bell-pair source at [4,5])  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two projector outcomes (symmetric vs. antisymmetric), encoded as distinct detector patterns across D0\u2026D5.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable & extensible:\n 1) First demonstration of the SWAP-test measurement in the polariton-wavelength DOF on an integrated chip.  \n 2) A key building block for quantum fingerprinting, entanglement routing and verification in wavelength-division networks.  \n 3) Once found, generalizes to higher-dimensional SWAP-tests (d>2) or parallel multi-qubit SWAP-tests on many wavelength channels.  \n 4) Fully within pytheus\u2019s abstraction: pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback control or non-linear elements needed.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The SWAP\u2010test is a well\u2010known \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d and \u201cintegrated photonic circuit\u201d into a new quantum-network primitive (no state-generation):\n   1) A 4-dimensional Bell-analyzer on chip using four polariton wavelengths.  \n   2) A two-channel wavelength-division multiplexed entanglement swap in one static circuit.  \n   3) A wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router: a static integrated circuit that, depending on the polariton-wavelength of a control photon, performs one of two entanglement-swapping operations between remote nodes A\u2013C or B\u2013D, and in superposition it yields a coherent superposition of which link was entangled.\n Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:\n   1) Too close to existing high-D Bell analyzers.  \n   2) Already flagged as parallelization of standard swaps.  \n   3) The controlled-router is genuinely new: it elevates entanglement swapping to a programmable, wavelength-encoded \u201cquantum router\u201d primitive, opening indefinite-order and multiplexed routing, and maps cleanly to Pytheus\u2019s resources (two pair sources, one single photon emitter as control, a static interferometer, number-resolving detectors).\n Step 3: I choose idea 3.\n Step 4: This is novel because no one has proposed a passive, wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router on an integrated chip that can coherently choose (or superpose) which pair of remote nodes to entangle.  \n Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only needs:\n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources (modes 0\u20131 and 2\u20133).  \n   \u2022 One single-photon emitter as a wavelength-encoded control qubit (mode 4).  \n   \u2022 A static linear-optical circuit (to be optimized).  \n   \u2022 Number-resolving detectors at the four node outputs plus two ancilla detectors.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of a wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router in an integrated photonic circuit. Instead of generating a fixed entangled state, the chip should perform one of two entanglement-swapping operations\u2014between remote nodes A&C or between B&D\u2014based solely on the polariton-wavelength of a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and if that photon is prepared in a superposition of the two wavelengths, the router will implement a coherent superposition of the two swap outcomes (a first step toward indefinite-order entanglement distribution). \n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]  (targets A & C)  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]  (targets B & D)  \n   \u2022 Single-photon control E \u2192 mode [4]  (prepared in |\u03bb\u2081\u27e9 or |\u03bb\u2082\u27e9 or their superposition)\n\n                   \u2193\n  integrated linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   D2 D3   D4 D5\n   (A  C)  (B  D)  (ctrl anc)\n\nOperation & targets:\n \u2022 If the control photon is in wavelength \u03bb\u2081, the linear network should route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the coherent sum of those two orderings, yielding a superposed entanglement link.  \n \u2022 The chip\u2019s success is heralded by distinct 3-click patterns: one signature for \u201cA\u2013C swapped,\u201d another for \u201cB\u2013D swapped,\u201d each correlated with which control-ancilla detector clicked.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled entanglement-swap router on chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (control emitter at mode 4)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4]  \n \u2022 pair sources: [[0,1], [2,3]]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two sets of detector-click signatures, one for each swap outcome, plus their coherent superposition.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this is powerful and extensible:\n 1) Introduces the first on-chip, passive quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength as a control qubit to choose and even superpose which remote link is entangled.  \n 2) Lays groundwork for indefinite-order entanglement distribution and multi-channel routing by simply adding more wavelengths and sources.  \n 3) Fully matches Pytheus\u2019s abstract model\u2014probabilistic pair sources, a single-photon emitter, a static interferometer, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014without requiring feedback or cavities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates existing controlled-swap and quantum-switch experiments already in the ensemble.
