It goes beyond point\u2010to\u2010point swapping or teleportation by fusing them into a genuine network\u2010coding primitive.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can optimize exactly this kind of static linear\u2010optical network fed by probabilistic pair\u2010sources and number\u2010resolving detectors. All elements (sources, interferometer, detectors) are within its abstraction; no dynamic feedback or cavities are required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the on\u2010chip implementation of the quantum network\u2010coding \u201cbutterfly\u201d node, realized in an integrated photonic circuit that exploits polariton\u2010wavelength multiplexing. The task is not to generate a fixed state but to carry out the two\u2010qubit teleportation network code\u2014two senders S\u2081 and S\u2082 each hold an unknown qubit encoded in two polariton wavelengths (\u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082). They both inject their photons into a single shared link (a wavelength\u2010division\u2010multiplexed waveguide) plus two local Bell\u2010pair sources. A static integrated circuit then performs the joint Bell\u2010measurements in the correct pattern so that the two qubits emerge at two separate receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082\u2014exactly as in the classical \u201cbutterfly\u201d network code, but now fully quantum.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Pair source A\u2013M \u2192 modes [0,1]\n   \u2022 Pair source B\u2013M \u2192 modes [2,3]\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit S\u2081 \u2192 mode [4] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit S\u2082 \u2192 mode [5] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 encoding)\n\n                   \u2193\n integrated static linear\u2010optical mesh (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors:\n   \u2022 D0,D1 (for BSM of S\u2081 with ancilla A\u2013M)\n   \u2022 D2,D3 (for BSM of S\u2082 with ancilla B\u2013M)\n   \u2022 D4,D5 (heralding pattern that encodes the network\u2010code \u201cXOR\u201d step)\n\nProcedure & targets:\n \u2022 S\u2081\u2019s qubit in mode 4 and one photon of source A\u2013M in mode 1 undergo a Bell\u2010measurement (BM\u2081) if the control of the internal coupler is set to route \u03bb\u2081 pulses.  \n \u2022 S\u2082\u2019s qubit in mode 5 and one photon of source B\u2013M in mode 3 undergo BM\u2082 if the routing is \u03bb\u2082.  \n \u2022 Both BMs share the same physical beamsplitter but are separated in the wavelength domain.  \n \u2022 The detectors D4/D5 record which combination of BSM outcomes occurred\u2014effectively computing the required \u201cXOR\u201d (network code) and heralding two teleported qubits at R\u2081 and R\u2082.  \n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cButterfly quantum network\u2010coding node via wavelength multiplexing.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n \u2022 num_anc: 0 additional ancilla (uses only the two Bell\u2010pair sources)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 input_modes: [4,5] (the two sender qubits)  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 target_operation: simultaneous teleportation of S\u2081\u2192R\u2081 and S\u2082\u2192R\u2082 using one shared interconnect, with herald clicks at D0\u2026D5 encoding the network code.  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy it\u2019s impactful and generalizable:\n 1) First on\u2010chip demonstration of quantum network coding in a genuine \u201cbutterfly\u201d configuration, harnessing polariton\u2010wavelength for multiplexing instead of bulk time\u2010bins or complex switching.  \n 2) Merges entanglement swapping, teleportation, and network coding into a single static circuit\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities\u2014perfectly fitting Pytheus\u2019s toolbox.  \n 3) Lays the foundation for scalable photonic quantum routers and repeaters that compress multiple communication channels into a single waveguide.  \n 4) Directly generalizable to larger network\u2010coding topologies (e.g. multi\u2010sender multicast codes) by adding wavelengths and pair sources in an integrated mesh.\n\nWe believe this target\u2014quantum network coding in a butterfly node via polariton\u2010wavelength multiplexing\u2014will inspire a family of new on\u2010chip quantum network experiments and can be realized by Pytheus\u2019s abstract optimization of noise.  \n2) It leverages discrete polariton wavelengths to multiplex purification operations, saving footprint and eliminating active switching.  \n3) Once found, the same design can be extended to If the input is in a superposition of \u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082, the router yields a coherent superposition of path A and path B. No dynamic switching or feedback is required\u2014only heralded post-selection.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit \u2192 mode 0 (encodes \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2081 \u2192 modes [1,2]  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2082 \u2192 modes [3,4]  \n             \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optics circuit  \n  (wavelength\u2010demultiplexer + two Bell\u2010measurement modules  \n   sharing the same beam-splitter mesh)  \n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2081 module  \n   D2 D3   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2082 module  \n   D4      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path A  \n   D5      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path B\n\nOperation:\n \u2022 The input photon at \u03bb\u2081 is routed by the demux into BSM\u2081 (mixing with ancilla modes 1&2). A coincidence at D0&D1 heralds teleportation onto ancilla mode 2, which we route to D4 (output A).  \n \u2022 Similarly, an input at \u03bb\u2082 is demuxed into BSM\u2082 (mixing modes 3&4), and D2&D3 click herald teleportation onto mode 4, routed to D5 (output B).  \n \u2022 If input = \u03b1|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+\u03b2|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9, the static network preserves coherence, producing {D0,D1,D4} or {D2,D3,D5}.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4]] to forbid \u03bb\u2081 input into the \u03bb\u2082 BSM and vice versa, enforcing clean demultiplexing.\n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable:\n 1) Introduces the first passive, heralded teleportation-based quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength encoding to choose the teleportation channel.     "output": "We propose as a Pytheus target the first on\u2010chip multi\u2010wavelength entanglement\u2010swapping router that can herald not just same\u2010color swaps, but also a cross\u2010frequency swap, all in one static linear\u2010optical circuit.  Instead of aiming to generate a state, the goal is a measurement network: two independent Bell\u2010pair sources\u2014one at polariton\u2010wavelength \u03bb\u2081, the other at \u03bb\u2082\u2014plus a single ancilla photon whose wavelength can be \u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082, or a superposition, feed a 6\u2010mode integrated interferometer.  Depending on which detectors click, the device unambiguously heralds one of three entanglement links:\n\n \u2022 \u201cSame\u2010\u03bb\u2081\u201d swap: photons in modes 0&1 (\u03bb\u2081) get entangled with modes 2&3 (\u03bb\u2081)  \n \u2022 \u201cSame\u2010\u03bb\u2082\u201d swap: modes 0&1 (\u03bb\u2082) \u2194 modes 2&3 (\u03bb\u2082)  \n \u2022 \u201cCross\u2010swap\u201d: mode-0 at \u03bb\u2081 becomes entangled with mode-3 at \u03bb\u2082, and mode-1/\u03bb\u2082 with mode-2/\u03bb\u2081  \n\nWhen the ancilla photon is prepared in a superposition |\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9, the interferometer coherently superposes these three swap outcomes\u2014a new network primitive for wavelength\u2010division quantum routing.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair @\u03bb\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair @\u03bb\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]  \n   \u2022 Single\u2010photon ancilla \u2192 mode [4] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082 qubit)  \n\n             \u2193\n static integrated linear mesh (to be optimized by Pytheus)  \n             \u2193\n detectors (number\u2010resolving):\n   D0 D1   D2 D3   D4 D5  \n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n description: \u201cMulti\u2010wavelength entanglement\u2010swap router with cross\u2010frequency channel.\u201d  \n pair_sources: [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n single_emitters: [4]  \n num_anc: 1  \n target_quantum: three distinct heralding\u2010click sets corresponding to the same\u2010\u03bb\u2081, same\u2010\u03bb\u2082, and cross\u2010\u03bb swap, plus their coherent superposition signatures.  \n number_resolving: True  \n removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this is exciting and generalizes:\n 1) Introduces a fundamentally new routing primitive: cross\u2010frequency entanglement swapping and its coherent superposition with same\u2010color swaps.  \n 2) Enables wavelength\u2010multiplexed quantum routers that dynamically select which channels to entangle, purely via passive linear optics and heralding\u2014no cavities or active switching.  \n 3) Generalizable to N wavelengths and M\u2010way cross\u2010swaps by adding more pair sources and ancilla colors.  \n 4) Fully within Pytheus\u2019s domain: abstract modes, probabilistic pair sources, single\u2010photon emitters, static interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"polariton wavelength\" and \"integrated photonic circuit\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. It tackles fundamental questions of nonlocality in triangular topologies rather than simple point-to-point swaps, and leverages integrated photonics plus wavelength encoding to distribute and measure three pair sources without dynamic feedback.\n  Step 5: Feasibility\u2014pytheus can handle three probabilistic pair sources, a static integrated interferometer (the chip), and number-resolving detectors at each node. No cavities or feedback needed. This framework maps cleanly onto pytheus\u2019s mode-and-source abstraction and can be generalized to larger polygonal networks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a target the on-chip realization of the \u201ctriangle\u201d quantum network\u2014three independent bipartite entangled sources (Bell pairs), each at a distinct polariton\u2010wavelength \u03bbA, \u03bbB, \u03bbC, injected into a single integrated photonic circuit that routes the six outputs to three spatially separated nodes (Alice, Bob, Charlie). Each node receives two modes at two different wavelengths (one from each of two sources), applies a fixed linear\u2010optic transformation (to be optimized), and performs photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection. The goal is to reproduce the nonclassical correlation pattern characteristic of the triangle network (violating any classical \u201cbilocal\u201d hidden\u2010variable bound) purely via passive optics and heralding\u2014no cavities, no feedback, no state generation.\n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; inputs (qubits equal) yield one unique detector-click signature, while antisymmetric inputs (qubits different) yield a different signature.  \n \u2022 By postselecting on these distinct click polariton wavelengths.  \n   2) A two-channel wavelength-division multiplexed entanglement swap in one static circuit.  \n   3) A wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router: a static integrated circuit that, depending on the polariton-wavelength of a control photon, performs one of two entanglement-swapping operations between remote nodes A\u2013C or B\u2013D, and in superposition it yields a coherent superposition of which link was entangled.\n Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:\n   1) Too close to existing high-D Bell analyzers.  \n   2) Already flagged as parallelization of standard swaps.  \n   3) The controlled-router is genuinely new: it elevates entanglement swapping to a programmable, wavelength-encoded \u201cquantum router\u201d primitive, opening indefinite-order and multiplexed routing, and maps cleanly to Pytheus\u2019s resources (two pair sources, one single photon emitter as control, a static interferometer, number-resolving detectors).\n Step 3: I choose idea 3.\n Step 4: This is novel because no one has proposed a passive, wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router on an integrated chip that can coherently choose (or superpose) which pair of remote nodes to entangle.  \n Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only needs:\n   \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources (modes 0\u20131 and detectors at the four node outputs plus two ancilla detectors.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of a wavelength-controlled entanglement-swapping router in an integrated photonic circuit. Instead of generating a fixed entangled state, the chip should perform one of two entanglement-swapping operations\u2014between remote nodes A&C or between B&D\u2014based solely on the polariton-wavelength of a single \u201ccontrol\u201d photon, and if that photon is prepared in a superposition of the two wavelengths, the router will implement a coherent superposition of the two swap outcomes (a first step toward indefinite-order entanglement distribution). \n\nGeneral structure (modes 0\u20135, top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5, left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]  (targets A & C)  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source S\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]  (targets B & D)  \n   \u2022 Single-photon control E \u2192 mode [4]  (prepared in |\u03bb\u2081\u27e9 or |\u03bb\u2082\u27e9 or their superposition)\n\n                   \u2193\n  integrated linear-optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus)\n                   \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   D2 D3   D4 D5\n   (A  C)  (B  D)  (ctrl anc)\n\nOperation & targets:\n \u2022 If the control photon is in wavelength \u03bb\u2081, the linear network should route S\u2081\u2019s ancilla modes to perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM) on modes 1&2, thereby swapping S\u2081 and S\u2082 to entangle modes 0&3 (i.e. A&C).  \n \u2022 If the control is in \u03bb\u2082, it instead routes S\u2082\u2019s modes to swap 0&1 with 3&2, entangling B&D.  \n \u2022 When control is in (|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9)/\u221a2, the circuit implements the coherent sum of those two orderings, yielding a superposed entanglement link.  \n \u2022 The chip\u2019s success is heralded by distinct 3-click patterns: one signature for \u201cA\u2013C swapped,\u201d another for \u201cB\u2013D swapped,\u201d each correlated with which control-ancilla detector clicked.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cWavelength-controlled entanglement-swap router on chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1 (control emitter at mode 4)  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [4]  \n \u2022 pair sources: [[0,1], [2,3]]  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two sets of detector-click signatures, one for each swap outcome, plus their coherent superposition.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this is powerful and extensible:\n 1) Introduces the first on-chip, passive quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength as a control qubit to choose and even superpose which remote link is entangled.  \n 2) Lays No cavities or active control are required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of an integrated-photonic entanglement-purification node exploiting polariton-wavelength multiplexing. Rather than generate a new state, the chip implements the standard two-pair purification protocol in the frequency domain: two imperfect Bell pairs\u2014one at \u03bb\u2081 (modes 0 & 1) and one at \u03bb\u2082 (modes 2 & 3)\u2014enter a passive static interferometer that demultiplexes the wavelengths, interferes one photon of each pair on a beam\u2010splitter mesh, and routes the others to two distant outputs (modes 4 & 5). Coincident detections on two ancilla detectors herald a high-fidelity Bell pair between the remaining photons.\n\nVisualization (modes numbered top\u2192bottom, detectors left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Bell pair source P\u2081 at \u03bb\u2081 \u2192 modes [0,1]\n   \u2022 Bell pair source P\u2082 at \u03bb\u2082 \u2192 modes [2,3]\n               \u2193\n integrated wavelength-demultiplexing + static beam-splitter network\n               \u2193\n detectors:\n   \u2022 D0, D1 (interference outputs for purification herald)\n   \u2022 D2, D3 (output channels for purified pair to remote nodes)\n\nKey Pytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cOn-chip entanglement purification via polariton-wavelength multiplexing.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: post-selection\u2014when detectors D0&D1 click in coincidence, modes 2&3 collapse into a purified Bell state.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: []  \n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:\n1) It is the first passive integrated demonstration of entanglement purification in the frequency domain, a crucial primitive for realistic quantum networks subject to loss and noise.  \n2) It leverages discrete polariton wavelengths to multiplex purification operations, saving footprint and eliminating active switching.  \n3) Once found, the same design can be extended to multiple purification stages or d-level purification by adding more wavelength channels and interferometric stages.  \n4) All elements\u2014probabilistic pair sources, static interferometer, number-resolving detectors\u2014are directly supported by Pytheus\u2019s abstract optimization framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement purification in linear optics\u2014whether via mode-division or frequency-division multiplexing\u2014has been covered. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201cpolariton wavelength\u201d and \u201cintegrated photonic circuit,\u201d avoiding state generation:\n    1) A 4-mode, on-chip Bell analyzer in four polariton wavelengths.\n    2) A dual-channel WDM entanglement swap in one passive chip.\n    3) A frequency-demultiplexed teleportation router: teleport an unknown frequency-encoded qubit onto one of two spatial outputs, controlled by its polariton wavelength, all via a static integrated circuit.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & fit:\n    \u2022 (1) is too close to existing high-D Bell proposals.\n    \u2022 (2) was flagged as mere parallelization.\n    \u2022 (3) is genuinely new\u2014a static, wavelength-controlled teleportation switch that converts frequency encoding into path encoding by teleportation, using only pair sources, linear optics, and detectors. Pytheus can optimize exactly this network.\n  Step 3: Choose idea 3.\n  Step 4: Novelty: First on-chip frequency-demultiplexed teleportation router\u2014combines polariton\u2010wavelength encoding and integrated photonics to realize a heralded routing of a qubit via teleportation, with no active feed-forward.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Uses two probabilistic pair sources (ancilla for \u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082), one unknown input photon in a wavelength superposition, a static linear interferometer with wavelength-selective couplers, and number-resolving detectors. All elements map directly to Pytheus\u2019s abstract model\u2014no cavities or feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose as a Pytheus target the design of a frequency-demultiplexed teleportation router on a single integrated photonic chip. The chip takes one unknown photonic qubit encoded in two discrete \u201cpolariton\u201d wavelengths (\u03bb\u2081, \u03bb\u2082) and, via two Bell-pair ancilla sources and a static linear\u2010optic network, teleports it onto one of two spatial output channels: output A for \u03bb\u2081, output B for \u03bb\u2082. If the input is in a superposition of \u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082, the router yields a coherent superposition of path A and path B. No dynamic switching or feedback is required\u2014only heralded post-selection.\n\nVisualization (modes 0\u20135 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D5 left\u2192right):\n\n emitters:\n   \u2022 Unknown qubit \u2192 mode 0 (encodes \u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082)  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2081 \u2192 modes [1,2]  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair ancilla at \u03bb\u2082 \u2192 modes [3,4]  \n             \u2193\n static integrated linear\u2010optics circuit  \n  (wavelength\u2010demultiplexer + two Bell\u2010measurement modules  \n   sharing the same beam-splitter mesh)  \n             \u2193\n detectors (number resolving):\n   D0 D1   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2081 module  \n   D2 D3   \u2190 BSM outputs for \u03bb\u2082 module  \n   D4      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path A  \n   D5      \u2190 herald\u2010edge detector for teleported path B\n\nOperation:\n \u2022 The input photon at \u03bb\u2081 is routed by the demux into BSM\u2081 (mixing with ancilla modes 1&2). A coincidence at D0&D1 heralds teleportation onto ancilla mode 2, which we route to D4 (output A).  \n \u2022 Similarly, an input at \u03bb\u2082 is demuxed into BSM\u2082 (mixing modes 3&4), and D2&D3 click herald teleportation onto mode 4, routed to D5 (output B).  \n \u2022 If input = \u03b1|\u03bb\u2081\u27e9+\u03b2|\u03bb\u2082\u27e9, the static network preserves coherence, producing \u03b1 at D4 and \u03b2 at D5, a frequency-to-path conversion by teleportation.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:\n \u2022 description: \u201cFrequency-demultiplexed teleportation router on integrated chip.\u201d  \n \u2022 pair_sources: [[1,2],[3,4]]  (ancilla for \u03bb\u2081 & \u03bb\u2082)  \n \u2022 num_anc: 0 single_emitters (all ancilla from pair_sources)  \n \u2022 input_modes: [0]  \n \u2022 single_emitters: []  \n \u2022 target_quantum: the two heralded projector outcomes\u2014\u201cteleported to A\u201d vs. \u201cteleported to B\u201d\u2014encoded as distinct click pairs {D0,D1,D4} or {D2,D3,D5}.  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4]] to forbid \u03bb\u2081 input into the \u03bb\u2082 BSM and vice versa, enforcing clean demultiplexing.\n\nWhy it\u2019s valuable:\n 1) Introduces the first passive, heralded teleportation-based quantum router that uses polariton-wavelength encoding to choose the teleportation channel.  \n 2) Converts frequency-encoded qubits into path-encoded ones via teleportation, a new network transformation primitive.  \n 3) Directly generalizes to N-wavelength demultiplexing or multi-output routing by adding more ancilla pair sources.  \n 4) Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: probabilistic pair sources, static linear optics (including wavelength demux simulated by removed_connections), and number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities or active feed-forward needed.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation     "output": "We propose as a Pytheus target the design of a passive on\u2010chip \u201cparity\u2010check\u201d node for three frequency\u2010bin qubits, encoded each into a single photon occupying one of two discrete polariton\u2010wavelength modes (\u03bb\u2081 or \u03bb\u2082). Rather than generate a state, the circuit implements a nondestructive measurement of the joint Z\u2297Z\u2297Z parity (i.e. whether an even or odd number of qubits lie in \u03bb\u2082) by mixing the three input photons with a small ancilla resource in a static linear interferometer and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n\nGeneral layout (modes 0\u20136 top\u2192bottom; detectors D0\u2026D6 left\u2192right):\n\nemitters:  \n  \u2022 Qubit A \u2192 modes [0,1] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n  \u2022 Qubit B \u2192 modes [2,3] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n  \u2022 Qubit C \u2192 modes [4,5] (\u03bb\u2081/\u03bb\u2082)  \n  \u2022 Ancilla single photon \u2192 mode [6]        \n\n             \u2193  \nstatic integrated linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus)  \n             \u2193  \ndetectors (number resolving): D0 D1 D2 D3 D4 D5 D6  \n\nHow it works:  \n \u2022 The three unknown qubits plus one ancilla photon enter a fixed network of beam splitters and wavelength\u2010selective couplers on chip.  \n \u2022 After interference, particular 4\u2010click patterns across D0\u2026D6 herald either \u201ceven parity\u201d (0 or 2 input photons in \u03bb\u2082) or \u201codd parity\u201d (1 or 3 input photons in \u03bb\u2082), without revealing any more information about the individual qubits.  \n \u2022 The single ancilla is reused coherently across the three input modes, so only one extra photon is needed.\n\nPytheus configuration hints:  \n \u2022 description: \u201cIntegrated frequency\u2010bin parity\u2010check node for three qubits.\u201d  \n \u2022 single_emitters: [6]  \n \u2022 num_anc: 1  \n \u2022 input_modes: [0,1,2,3,4,5] (the three qubits)  \n \u2022 target_quantum: two projector outcomes (even vs. odd parity), each defined by a disjoint set of click\u2010patterns across D0\u2026D6  \n \u2022 number_resolving: True  \n \u2022 removed_connections: none  \n\nWhy this is interesting & generalizable:  \n1) Performs a fundamental multi\u2010qubit network measurement (parity check) in the frequency domain on a monolithic photonic chip\u2014no feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n2) A key primitive for error\u2010syndrome extraction, entanglement purification, and cluster\u2010state fusion in wavelength\u2010division quantum networks.  \n3) Immediately extensible to N\u2010qubit parity checks or to d\u2010level \u201cmod\u2010d\u201d checks by adding ancilla and wavelengths.  \n4) Fully within Pytheus\u2019s abstract model of probabilistic sources, static linear optics, and number\u2010resolving detection."
